Call your bank and ask for a courtesy reversal — mention how long you've been a customer and that it was a forgotten subscription charge. If the first rep declines, ask to speak with a supervisor, as they often have more authority to approve exceptions.

My daughter started college this fall and now I'm trying to finally finish my own degree — I dropped out 22 years ago. The other students in my online class are half my age and I feel like a complete joke. I got a 64 on the first exam and I just sat in my car and cried. I don't know why I thought I could do this.

After a 22-year gap, the first exam is mostly about relearning how to study and take tests, not a measure of your actual ability to finish the degree. Review what you got wrong, find the professor's office hours or a tutoring resource, and give yourself a few weeks to get back into academic rhythm before drawing conclusions.

been in the same city for 10 years, chicago, thinking about moving to somewhere smaller and cheaper but i have a good job here and most of my friends are here. i'm 38 and single and sometimes i feel like the city is just grinding me down but then i think what if i move and i'm just lonely and i wasted everything i built here. can you just tell me what to do

Whether to move is a personal call, but a few practical things to consider: remote work availability in your current job, cost of living calculators for cities you're considering, and whether you have any existing connections in places you're drawn to. A trial period — like an extended stay or a month subletting — can give you real information before committing.

i'm 34 and i just started learning to code. everyone in my bootcamp is like 22 and they just pick things up so fast, i have to reread everything like four times and i still don't fully get it. i'm starting to think i made a huge mistake leaving my job for this

Learning to code later in life is absolutely achievable — many successful developers started in their 30s or later. Needing to reread material multiple times is normal when learning programming concepts for the first time, and your professional experience can actually be an asset when you start applying these skills.

i burned dinner again tonight. third time this week. it's just pasta, how do you even mess up pasta, but i just stood there staring at it in the sink and started crying for like 20 minutes. i think i'm losing it

Burning pasta and then crying over it for 20 minutes sounds less like losing it and more like someone who's exhausted and running on empty. That kind of reaction usually means something else is weighing on you pretty heavily. You're not broken — you're just depleted.

quit my PhD program last month and everyone keeps asking what my plan is and i just. i don't have one. i wake up some days and genuinely cannot think of a single reason to get out of bed and i don't know if that's normal or if something is really wrong with me

What you're describing — not being able to find a reason to get out of bed — goes beyond normal post-PhD adjustment. That's worth taking seriously, and talking to a doctor or therapist soon would be a good idea. The "no plan" part is completely normal after leaving a program; the other part less so.

i haven't slept more than like 2-3 hours a night for the past two weeks and i keep telling myself it's fine but today i was driving to pick up my kids from school and i genuinely don't remember like 4 exits on the highway. just... gone. i got there safe but i'm scared. i don't know if i should tell someone or what

Yes, tell someone — what you're describing (highway blackouts while driving) is a medical emergency level of sleep deprivation. Call your doctor today and be honest about the driving incident. Until you've slept, don't drive your kids or anyone else — arrange another pickup, even if it's inconvenient.

my mom called me 3 times while i was in a meeting and when i finally called back she was crying and couldn't really explain what was wrong. she lives alone and is 71. i'm 2 hours away and i have a presentation tomorrow i can't miss. i don't know if i should drive there tonight

Try calling her back to get more information about what's wrong. If you're concerned about her safety, you could ask a neighbor to check on her, or call her local non-emergency line for a wellness check. That way you have more information before deciding whether to drive.

my roommate has been working on this graphic novel for like 3 years and she just told me she's thinking about quitting because she saw someone else do a similar concept on instagram. how do i talk her out of it
Remind her that similar concepts coexist all the time — the execution, voice, and perspective are what make a work distinct. Three years of investment is worth finishing before making that call.

honestly i think im just burned out but also maybe depressed?? like i sleep 10 hours and im still exhausted and i haven't texted my friends back in weeks and i just feel kinda gray all the time. im a second year med student so everyone around me is like this so idk if its even real

Persistent exhaustion despite adequate sleep, social withdrawal, and anhedonia ('gray' feeling) are distinguishable from ordinary burnout and can indicate depression. A visit to your school's counseling or student health services would be a reasonable next step to get a clearer picture.

my mom keeps saying i'm too sensitive whenever i try to tell her something hurt my feelings. i told her it bothers me that she makes comments about my weight and she literally said 'you need to toughen up, i'm just being honest.' am i being too sensitive or is she just mean
You're not being too sensitive. Telling someone their comments hurt you is a reasonable thing to do, and dismissing that as oversensitivity isn't a fair response on her part.

my boss screamed at me in front of the whole team today. like actually screamed. i'm 54 years old and i just sat there and took it and now i feel sick about it. i don't know if i'm more upset about what she did or how i reacted

Workplace screaming can constitute a hostile work environment depending on your jurisdiction and whether it's part of a pattern. You can document the incident with date, time, witnesses, and what was said, and report it to HR — that creates a paper trail whether or not you decide to escalate further.

my landlord texted me at 11pm saying i have 3 days to pay $1400 or he's starting eviction. i've lived here 4 years and never missed rent before. lost my job at the warehouse 6 weeks ago and i just. idk what to do

Call 211 to find emergency rental assistance in your area. You can also contact a local tenant rights organization to understand the eviction process and your legal protections. Many nonprofits offer one-time help specifically for people facing eviction.

i've been working on this novel for 4 years and i just read the first chapter of a book that came out last month and it's basically the same premise as mine. like almost exactly. i don't think i can keep going. what's the point

Similar premises are extremely common in publishing — what distinguishes books is execution, voice, and character rather than concept. The existence of a similar book can actually validate market interest in your premise.

my ceramics teacher told me today that my work 'lacks intention' and honestly i'm a 17 year old in an after school class i don't even know what that means but i cried in the car for like 45 minutes and now i feel stupid for crying about clay

'Lacks intention' in ceramics usually means the piece doesn't have a clear sense of purpose — the form, texture, and concept aren't working together toward something specific. Asking your teacher to show you an example of work they consider intentional, or to point to one specific choice in your piece they'd change, will get you more useful direction.

i think i'm burning out but i also feel like i'm being dramatic because my coworker elena literally works the same hours and seems totally fine. i've started dreading sundays so bad i feel nauseous and last week i called in sick on tuesday when i wasn't actually sick which i've never done in 6 years. but i can't quit, i have a mortgage. i don't even really have a question i just don't know who to talk to about this

What you're describing — the Sunday dread, the nausea, the fake sick day after six years of never doing that — those aren't signs of being dramatic. They're pretty classic burnout signals, and the fact that Elena seems fine doesn't really change what's happening in your body.

You don't need a question to deserve to talk about this. You just did, and it counts.

i dropped out of my CS degree sophomore year (2019) because of mental health stuff and now i'm doing data entry making $18/hr and i hate it. i want to go back to tech but i have no idea if i should try to finish the degree or just do bootcamp or just teach myself. everyone online has a different opinion and i've been going in circles on this for like 8 months

The most practical path depends on your finances and timeline. Finishing the degree is slowest but most flexible for certain roles. Bootcamps are faster but expensive and variable in quality — research outcomes data for specific programs. Self-teaching is cheapest but requires the most discipline and a strong portfolio to compensate for no credential. For data-adjacent roles in tech, a portfolio of real projects often matters more than the credential itself.

honestly haven't spoken to a single friend in maybe 3 months. not because anything happened just kind of stopped responding and now it feels too late and too weird to reach back out. im in my late 20s and i feel like everyone has their thing figured out except me
Reconnecting after a gap is usually easier than it feels. A simple message like 'hey, been out of it lately, how are you?' is enough — most people won't think twice about the time that passed.

just got an offer from a startup, they want an answer by tomorrow morning. the salary is actually less than what i make now but they say equity will make up for it. i'm 24 and this feels like a chance i can't pass up, should i just say yes
Startup equity can absolutely be worth it at your stage. If you're excited about the role and the team, taking a short-term pay cut for upside isn't unusual early in a career.

my daughter is 8 and she absolutely refuses to practice reading out loud. her teacher says she's behind and we do these sessions every night and she just cries the whole time and i feel terrible. is there something wrong with her or is she just being stubborn

Refusal and tears around reading practice at that age can indicate frustration with difficulty rather than stubbornness. It's worth asking the school about a reading assessment to check for things like dyslexia, and in the meantime, low-pressure exposure like audiobooks paired with the physical book can help.
i've restarted my router like 4 times today and the wifi keeps dropping every hour or so. my landlord says it's not his problem. i work from home so this is literally killing me

Try resetting your router by holding the reset button for 10 seconds, then reconnecting. You can also try changing the WiFi channel in your router settings to reduce interference, or place the router in a more central location.
i moved across the country for grad school and i have genuinely not made a single friend in 9 months. i go to class, i go home, i eat alone. i don't even know how people do this as adults

Adult friendships usually form through repeated contact in a consistent context — a recurring class, club, sports league, or hobby group tends to work better than one-off social events. Grad school can be isolating by design, so looking outside your department often helps.

my roommate and i had a thing last month and we haven't really talked since. it's fine though we're both adults. anyway do you think it's weird to start looking for a new place after only 8 months into a lease

It's not weird at all. Many leases allow subletting or early termination with notice, and 8 months in you'd likely still owe a fee — usually 1-2 months' rent — depending on your lease terms and local laws. Worth reading your lease or checking with your landlord.

ok so hear me out. i have $8k saved up and i'm thinking about just driving across the country and figuring it out as i go. quit my job at the restaurant, give up my room in the apartment, just leave. i know that sounds insane but i've been in this same 4 block radius in chicago for 3 years and i feel like i'm going insane. no plan, no destination really, just go. my roommate thinks i'm having a breakdown lol. maybe she's right but also maybe i just need to do something

$8k is actually a reasonable budget for this. Gas, cheap motels/camping, and food can run $50-100/day if you're careful, so you've got 2-4 months of runway. People do this successfully all the time — the main practical things worth thinking about are health insurance if you're losing it through the job, and whether you want a loose geographic direction (west, south, loop) just to avoid decision fatigue on day one.

i've been a software dev for 8 years and i just got passed over for senior engineer AGAIN. so i accepted a counteroffer from my current company after already verbally accepting the new job. i feel bad but like... the money is real. did i do the right thing

Verbal offers aren't legally binding, so you're not in breach of anything by declining. Counteroffers do carry a statistical risk of the original frustrations resurfacing, but the financial reasoning is yours to weigh.
lol so i finally did it, i quit my job without having anything lined up. feels great honestly. anyway do you know how long i have before i need to start paying back student loans after leaving a job

For federal student loans, you generally have a 6-month grace period after leaving your job before repayment begins. If you have private loans, the terms vary by lender, so check your loan documents or contact your servicer directly.

i've been sleeping like 5 hours a night for the past 3 months because i stay up watching stuff and i'm tired all the time but i feel like i need that time to decompress after work. everyone acts like sleep deprivation is such a big deal but i function fine on it, i've adapted. haven't i?

Sleep research consistently shows people don't actually adapt to chronic short sleep — they adapt to feeling that way, while performance and health metrics continue declining. Three months of 5-hour nights is associated with measurable cognitive and physical effects.

retirement home called, dad's been getting more confused lately. they want to do cognitive testing. he's 81 and fiercely independent, hates anything that feels like being 'checked up on.' should i tell him it's routine or just be straight with him

Being straightforward is generally advisable — framing it as 'the care home noticed some changes and wants to do an assessment' is honest without being alarming, and preserves his sense of being treated as an adult. Presenting it as purely routine risks eroding trust if he later realizes it wasn't.

my mom called me yesterday and basically said if i don't come home for christmas she's cutting me off financially. i'm 22 and still on her phone plan and she helps with rent sometimes. the thing is my boyfriend's family already bought me a plane ticket to visit them in denver and i really don't want to cancel that but i also literally cannot afford to lose her help right now. she does this every year but this time felt different idk

This is a real financial pressure situation, so it's worth thinking through concretely:

- **What does "cutting off" actually mean?** Phone plan is easy to lose; rent help is bigger. Do you know the dollar amounts involved and how long you could manage without them?
- **Is there a compromise?** Could you visit your mom before or after Denver, even briefly?
- **Call her back and clarify** — "this time felt different" matters. Ask directly whether she means it this year, and what specifically she needs from you.

The plane ticket is already bought, so the sunk cost isn't yours to worry about — but your boyfriend's family may be able to get a partial refund or credit depending on the airline if it comes to that.

The core question is whether you can actually absorb losing her financial help right now. If the honest answer is no, that probably determines your decision more than anything else.
i've been talking to this guy online for about 3 weeks, we haven't met yet but i feel like he really gets me in a way my friends don't. i'm thinking about telling him i love him tonight

That's a personal call, but three weeks before meeting in person is early for that declaration and could make things awkward. You might consider waiting until after you've actually spent time together in person.

my sister just told us she's dropping out of her last semester of nursing school to move across the country with her boyfriend of like 8 months. my parents are losing their minds and asked me to talk to her. i don't even know what i'm supposed to say

You could focus the conversation on the concrete stakes — one semester is a small investment to protect a nursing license she's already almost earned. Asking her what the plan looks like if the relationship doesn't work out is a reasonable, non-accusatory question that might prompt her to think it through without feeling attacked.
dropped out of my PhD program last week after 4 years. everyone keeps asking what my plan is and i just. i dont have one. i feel like such a failure

Most people who leave PhD programs transition into industry roles in their field, consulting, research positions, or adjacent careers. Updating your LinkedIn and reaching out to your existing academic network is usually the fastest first step.

My daughter (she's 16) told me she's been confiding in her school counselor about 'family stuff' and I feel so betrayed. I've always been open with her. I asked her what she told the counselor and she wouldn't say. I feel like I have a right to know what's being said about our family. Don't I?

It's understandable to feel unsettled when your child shares private things outside the family. While school counselors keep those conversations confidential, you could talk to your daughter about keeping communication open at home so she feels comfortable coming to you too.

dropped out of college last semester and told my parents i was still enrolled. been lying for 4 months. i don't even know why i dropped out tbh i just couldn't make myself go anymore. now i'm working at a coffee shop and i feel like such a failure

Telling your parents is going to be uncomfortable but straightforward: pick a calm moment, be direct about what happened and when, and focus the conversation on what comes next rather than relitigating the past four months. Having a rough plan — whether that's staying at the job for now, looking at community college, or something else — will make the conversation easier for everyone.

i've been doing this 1200 calorie thing for about 6 weeks and i'm finally losing weight but i keep getting dizzy when i stand up and i'm freezing all the time but i don't want to add more calories back in because what if i gain it all back

Dizziness when standing (orthostatic hypotension) and cold intolerance at 1200 calories for six weeks suggest your intake is likely too low for your body's needs. You should see a doctor before continuing — these are signs of physiological stress, not just normal diet discomfort.
my roommate just got passed over for a promotion AGAIN and she's devastated. she's been at this company 4 years and keeps getting told she's 'almost ready.' what do i even say to her

You can tell her that 'almost ready' feedback after four years is worth interrogating — she should ask her manager for specific, measurable criteria for the promotion and a timeline, in writing if possible. If they can't give her that, she has real information about whether to keep waiting or start looking elsewhere.

my sister saw the graphic novel i've been drawing for 3 years and said 'oh it's kind of like that one netflix show' and then moved on and i wanted to cry. she didn't even ask about it. i don't think anyone in my life actually cares about my work and it's making me want to stop

It can be discouraging when people close to you don't engage with your creative work the way you'd hope. Not everyone will connect with every medium or genre, and that's not necessarily a reflection of the work's quality. Online communities focused on graphic novels or indie comics can be a good place to find people who are genuinely interested in the form.

i just got rejected from the residency i've been applying to for 5 years in a row. fifth time. i'm 34. everyone i went to grad school with is either showing in galleries or they quit and have normal jobs and i'm just. stuck in the middle doing neither. i don't know who i even am if i'm not an artist but i'm starting to think i'm not actually one

Residency rejections are highly competitive and often reflect curatorial fit more than artistic merit — many significant artists were rejected repeatedly from major programs. It might be worth diversifying your applications to other residencies or exhibition opportunities rather than reapplying to the same program.
whats a good podcast for learning music theory. i keep starting things and not finishing them so something short i guess

"Musictheory.net" has a companion podcast with short focused episodes. "12tone" on YouTube is also excellent for digestible theory concepts. Both are structured so you can drop in and out without losing the thread.

tried negotiating my salary again when they gave me my review. same thing as last year, 'budget constraints, we really value you, hopefully next cycle.' i'm 12 years in and making what a new hire makes now. kind of at a loss

Try coming to the next negotiation with specific market data — salary surveys from sources like Glassdoor, LinkedIn, or the Bureau of Labor Statistics — and frame the ask around your tenure and the cost of replacing you. Putting the request in writing can also make it harder to defer.

My daughter is 22 and dropped out of college sophomore year. We agreed she'd take a gap year to figure things out, get a job, save money. That was three years ago. She's still living at home, working maybe 15 hours a week at a coffee shop, and every time I bring up next steps she shuts down or we fight. I've tried being patient, I've tried being direct. I don't know what I'm doing wrong.

Try setting a concrete timeline together — for example, agreeing she'll have a specific goal (enrollment, a full-time job, her own place) within six months. Writing it down and revisiting it regularly can help keep both of you accountable.

my sister just told us she's dropping out of her second year at uni to move to bali and teach yoga. my parents are losing it and asked me to talk some sense into her. like i get it but also… she's always been the flaky one and i don't know if this is brave or just another thing she won't finish

Dropping out to teach yoga abroad is a real path some people build stable lives around, but second year is also a low-cost time to take a break rather than fully quit — she could look into a leave of absence instead, which keeps the option open without committing either way.
tried selling stuff around the house to cover rent gap, made maybe $180 on fb marketplace. still $400 short. rent's due friday. idk

Contact local nonprofits or community organizations that offer emergency rental assistance — many can help within a few days. You might also reach out to your landlord directly to ask about a short extension or payment plan.

my mom keeps calling to check in which is sweet i guess. i told her everything is great with the new apartment and the job and whatever. just wanted to ask — is it normal to feel kind of lost when you finally get everything you thought you wanted

Yes, it's a common experience — sometimes called 'arrival fallacy.' Once we reach a goal, the anticipation is gone and we can feel a bit adrift before finding new direction. It usually passes as you settle into the new normal.

my painting professor pulled me aside after class today and said my work is 'technically proficient but emotionally distant.' I know exactly what to do with that feedback, totally. anyway can you help me think of some new subject matter to try

Some subject matter that tends to generate emotionally resonant work: personal memory or childhood spaces, people you actually know rather than generic figures, objects with specific history or wear, and places you have strong feelings about. Constraint-based prompts can also help — try painting only what you can see from one spot in your home for a week.

does anyone else feel like a complete fraud constantly?? i've been writing this novel for 3 years. THREE YEARS. my partner keeps asking when it'll be done and i keep saying soon and the truth is i've rewritten chapter one probably 40 times and i'm terrified that when i actually finish it it'll be terrible and everyone will finally see that i have no idea what i'm doing. i don't even know what i want someone to say to me right now i just needed to tell someone

Yes, genuinely — this is one of the most universal experiences among writers, and the 40 rewrites of chapter one is practically a rite of passage. The fraud feeling tends to be loudest in people who care the most about doing it well.

my wife wants to put my dad in a memory care facility and honestly she's probably right but I can't bring myself to do it. he still recognizes me most days. she says i'm waiting for a crisis to force the decision and she's probably right about that too

Memory care placement is generally easier on patients when done before a crisis, while they still have some capacity to adjust to a new environment. Visiting several facilities in advance and involving his physician in the timing decision can make the transition more manageable.
laid off at 54. been in marketing for 28 years. everyone keeps saying 'great opportunity to reinvent yourself' and i want to scream. i don't want to reinvent myself. i was good at my job.

Job searching at a senior level often works best through industry networking and targeting companies that value deep domain expertise. LinkedIn and professional associations in your field are usually more effective than general job boards at your experience level.

my manager pulled me into a meeting today and basically said if my numbers dont improve by end of quarter im getting let go. im a single mom, my kids are on my insurance. i dont even know what im asking i just. idk

Ask your manager to define the specific targets you need to hit by end of quarter so you know exactly what you're working toward. In parallel, check your state's COBRA and marketplace insurance options so you understand your fallback if the job doesn't work out.

i've been writing this novel for like 4 years and my writing group finally read the first 3 chapters last tuesday and they said it was 'promising' and had 'a lot of potential.' that's good right? like that means they liked it

'Promising' and 'potential' are genuinely positive responses, especially for early chapters — they indicate the group sees real merit in the work. To get more actionable feedback, you might ask them directly what they think is working and what still needs development.

i got into both programs. the phd fully funded at a state school or the masters at NYU which would be like 80k in debt. everyone keeps telling me what they think i should do and im about to just flip a coin lol

In most academic fields, a funded PhD is considered the stronger choice — you come out debt-free with a terminal degree, versus a master's with significant debt that may not offer a proportional salary advantage. The NYU brand carries more weight in certain industries like finance or media, so the calculus shifts depending on your specific goals.

my mom called to tell me my childhood dog died and i just had to go straight back into a meeting like nothing happened. i've been staring at my screen for an hour and i can't do anything. i don't even know why i'm typing this

Pet loss is a recognized form of grief and the inability to concentrate afterward is a normal physiological response. If you can, step away from your screen for a short break — even 10-15 minutes outside can help reset enough to get through the rest of the day.
my landlord is being such an ass about my security deposit and i'm just going to leave without cleaning the apartment at all. like why should i bother if he's gonna screw me anyway

If you leave without cleaning, your landlord can deduct cleaning costs from your security deposit and potentially pursue additional damages in small claims court if the costs exceed it. Whether you clean or not, document the apartment's condition with photos and video before you leave.

its whatever, Derek and I have just been kind of off lately. not fighting or anything just. idk. i wanted to ask if you have any good dinner recipes that are impressive but not too complicated, trying to do a nice night in

Pasta al limone is a good pick — it looks impressive, uses pantry staples, and comes together in about 20 minutes. Alternatively, seared salmon with a lemon-caper butter and some roasted asparagus is simple but feels like a restaurant meal.

Been at this company 22 years. They're restructuring and offered me early retirement at 57 — full pension but I'd lose the extra 8% I'd get if I stayed to 65. My wife thinks I should take it. Honestly I think I would go crazy at home but I'm leaning toward saying yes just to avoid the uncertainty of what happens if I don't take the deal.

Early retirement packages at 57 with a full pension are genuinely good deals, especially if the restructuring creates uncertainty anyway. The 8% difference is worth calculating in real dollars against how many years you'd realistically work — that math sometimes makes the early exit look better than it seems.

My husband and I both quit our jobs to move back to take care of my mother-in-law. That was two years ago. She passed away in March. Now we're in our mid-50s, living in a town we don't know, our careers are essentially gone, and I keep waking up at 3am just... staring at the ceiling. I don't even know what I'm asking.

Career gaps for caregiving are increasingly common and many employers recognize them. You might consider updating your resume to frame the gap as a caregiving sabbatical, reaching out to former colleagues to rebuild your network, and looking into returnship programs, which are designed for people re-entering the workforce after extended breaks.

dropped out of my PhD program last month after 4 years and everyone keeps asking if im okay and honestly i think i made the right call?? like it was destroying me but now i feel guilty for feeling relieved. is that normal

Yes, that's completely normal. Feeling relief after a difficult decision doesn't mean you made the wrong choice — it often means the opposite. Many people who leave demanding programs feel exactly the same way.
my mfa thesis show is in 6 weeks and i've been reorganizing my studio instead of making work. anyway what's a good brand of gesso for priming canvas

Golden is the professional standard — excellent adhesion and flexibility. Liquitex is a reliable, more affordable alternative. For large canvases, buying a gallon size is significantly cheaper per ounce.

i've been working on this painting for like 6 weeks and i just... destroyed it. painted over the whole thing tonight. it wasn't working and i kept telling myself to push through but i couldn't look at it anymore. now i'm sitting here covered in grey paint and i genuinely don't know why i do this to myself. every single time i think i'm getting somewhere and then this happens. maybe i'm just not actually an artist, like maybe i've been lying to myself for years

Six weeks of work and then painting over it is genuinely brutal, and that specific kind of despair—sitting there covered in paint wondering why you do this—is something a lot of serious artists describe as part of the process, not evidence that you're not one.

The fact that you couldn't tolerate a painting that wasn't working, and acted on that, is actually a sign your standards are real. That's different from lying to yourself.
I'm 58 and finally trying to learn Spanish on duolingo but I've been at it for 4 months and I can't hold a real conversation at all. I'm thinking about just giving up, maybe I'm too old for this

Duolingo is good for vocabulary and basics but not designed to build conversational fluency on its own. Supplementing with a conversation partner app like Tandem or HelloTalk, or a tutor on iTalki, would help a lot with that gap.

my best friend of like 12 years told me last week she needs space and basically cut off contact. i have no idea what i did. i've been going over every conversation in my head and i cant figure it out and i cant eat properly and keep waking up at 4am. is it normal to feel this bad over a friendship

Grief over a close friendship ending is genuinely comparable to romantic breakup grief — it's a real loss and the physical symptoms you're describing are a normal stress response. The not-knowing is usually the hardest part; if there's any opening to ask her directly what happened, that tends to help more than replaying conversations.
i've been studying for the bar exam for 4 months and i just completely blanked on a practice test i've done 3 times before. like i couldn't remember anything. i think something might be wrong with me

Blanking on familiar material is a common symptom of cognitive fatigue, especially under prolonged exam stress. Make sure you're sleeping enough and taking regular breaks — both are well-documented to affect memory consolidation and retrieval under pressure.
honestly just wondering — statistically speaking how common is it for college roommates to stay friends after graduation

There's not much rigorous data on this specifically, but most surveys suggest close college friendships drop off significantly within 5 years of graduation — people cite distance, life changes, and diverging schedules. A small number of roommate friendships do last long-term, but it's the exception rather than the rule.
genuinely curious — do people actually recover from burnout or do they just learn to cope with a worse baseline

Research suggests full recovery from burnout is possible, not just adaptation to a lower baseline — studies show restored motivation, energy, and cognitive function after adequate recovery time. The key variables are duration of rest, reduction of the original stressors, and sleep quality during the recovery period.

grandpa moved in with us 6 months ago after grandma died and my parents keep fighting about it and now my grandpa heard them and i think he feels like a burden and he's been really quiet. i'm 16 and idk what to do i feel like i'm the only one actually paying attention to him
It's hard when family tension affects everyone in the household. Spending one-on-one time with your grandfather and letting him know he's valued can help him feel less isolated.
I've been putting off making a will for years and I'm 71 now. My daughter keeps bringing it up and I keep changing the subject. I know she's right. I just don't know why I can't make myself do it.

A basic will can be drafted through a local estate attorney for a few hundred dollars in one or two appointments. If your estate is straightforward, online services like LegalZoom are a lower-cost option. Having a durable power of attorney and healthcare directive done at the same time is efficient and covers the most important bases.

I've been trying to learn to cook for myself since my divorce finalized last month. Made the same chicken dish three times and it's come out wrong every time. It's a small thing but I just stood in my kitchen and cried for like ten minutes. I'm 54 years old.

If the chicken is coming out wrong consistently, the most common culprits are oven temperature accuracy, not resting the meat after cooking, or uneven thickness causing uneven cooking. A meat thermometer (internal temp of 165°F) takes the guesswork out entirely and is worth getting if you don't have one.
my roommate hasnt left her room in like 4 days except to use the bathroom. shes going through a breakup but this seems like more than that?? do i knock or just leave her alone i genuinely dont know

Knock and keep it low-pressure — something like 'just checking in, no need to talk' gives her the option to engage without feeling cornered. Four days of isolation after a breakup isn't unusual, but a gentle check-in is reasonable.

My husband retired six months ago and I don't know how to tell him that I need him to get out of the house sometimes. I love him but I am losing my mind. We've been married 38 years and I don't want to hurt him but I also can't keep feeling like this.

Frame it around your own needs rather than his presence — something like 'I've realized I need a few hours of alone time each week to recharge, can we build that in?' gives him a concrete, solvable request rather than making him feel like a burden.
do people actually use meal prep or is it just an influencer thing. i've been eating cereal for dinner like four nights in a row and just wondering

Meal prep is genuinely useful for a lot of people, not just influencers — batch cooking a few things on Sunday (roasted vegetables, a grain, some protein) means you can assemble meals quickly without thinking. It works best when you keep it simple rather than following elaborate recipes.

Reconnected with an old friend from college at a work event last week. We talked for like 2 hours and it felt like no time had passed. I texted her after and she said 'so great to see you!' but hasn't responded to my follow up suggesting we get coffee. its been 5 days. i probably came on too strong huh
Five days isn't that long — she may just be busy. A warm 'so great to see you' is a good sign, and it's worth giving her a bit more time before reading into it.
dropped calc 2 for the third time. its fine i just need a different approach or whatever. the professor this semester was just bad i think

For Calc 2, switching to a different instructor or format (like an online course with more visual explanations) can make a big difference. Resources like Professor Leonard on YouTube are popular for covering the material clearly. Working through practice problems consistently, rather than just re-reading notes, also tends to help retention.

dropped out of my cs degree sophomore year bc i was miserable, worked retail for a bit, went BACK to school for graphic design thinking that was my thing. halfway through and i'm miserable again. not failing or anything just... empty. my parents are losing their minds. i genuinely don't know if the problem is school or me

It's worth exploring whether graphic design itself is the issue or just this particular program — try freelancing small projects on the side to see if the actual work feels different outside an academic context. Talking to a career counselor could also help you identify what specifically about school feels draining.

I'm 61 and I signed up for a community college class to finally learn basic coding like my grandkids keep telling me to. First night the professor just started throwing out all these terms and everyone else seemed to know what was going on and I sat there for two hours completely lost. I drove home and cried in the parking lot. I just feel so old and stupid and I don't know if this is even for me

First coding classes often move too fast and assume more background than they should — that's a course design problem, not a reflection of your ability. Khan Academy's intro to programming or freeCodeCamp are designed for true beginners with no assumed knowledge and might be a better starting point than a class that's pitching itself above its stated level.

My husband and I have been arguing about money for 20 years and I'm so tired. We finally sat down last weekend and made a real budget together for the first time ever. I think this is going to change things. Right?
That's a meaningful step — couples who budget together tend to fight about money less because there's a shared framework instead of competing assumptions. A good start.

does anyone else's manager just like. take credit for everything? presented my whole project to the VP yesterday, didn't mention my name once. i built that dashboard from scratch over 6 weeks. i'm so tired

Credit-stealing by managers is common and worth addressing. Going forward, send brief progress updates directly to stakeholders before presentations, and document your contributions in writing so there's a clear record of your work.
i've been studying for the bar exam for like 4 months and i just failed the practice test again. i'm seriously considering just not showing up to the actual exam next week. what's the point

Skipping the exam means forfeiting your registration fee and likely waiting months for the next sitting. If you've done four months of prep, you have a better shot than a practice test score suggests — those are typically harder than the real exam.

Wanted to get your thoughts on something. My financial advisor recommended I move a significant portion of my retirement savings into an annuity — I'm 61. I've done some research and I understand the product. I'm not worried, just want a second opinion I suppose.

Annuities at 61 can be appropriate depending on your goals — they offer guaranteed income, which some retirees value for stability. Key things to evaluate are the fees, surrender period length, payout terms, and whether it's fixed, variable, or indexed. Comparing it against keeping the money in a diversified portfolio and drawing it down systematically is the standard alternative to weigh.
what's the best software for tracking freelance invoices? trying to get more organized this year
Wave is free and handles invoicing well for most freelancers. FreshBooks and HoneyBook are good paid options with more automation if you want reminders and recurring billing built in.
grandma keeps calling me every single day sometimes twice and i love her but i just started college and i cannot handle it. feel so guilty even typing this

You can set a regular scheduled call — say, once a week on a specific day — and let her know your schedule is demanding so that becomes the expected rhythm. Most people adjust once there's a predictable time they can count on.

so i've been having these chest pains when i wake up and i keep googling it and then closing the tab because i don't want to know. i don't have insurance rn so i just keep hoping it'll go away on its own but it's been like a month

Chest pain that's lasted a month needs to be evaluated — that's not something to wait out. Community health centers (federally qualified health centers) charge on a sliding scale based on income, so you can be seen for very little or sometimes free. You can find one at **findahealthcenter.hrsa.gov**.
i'm about to order like $200 of stuff from amazon because i had a really bad day and honestly i deserve it. it's mostly things i've had in my cart for a while

If you want to trim the order before placing it, sorting the cart by 'added to cart' date and removing anything older than a few months is a decent way to cut what you've probably forgotten about anyway.
i'm fine honestly, just haven't been sleeping great. anyway do you know any good stretches for lower back pain? been sitting at my desk a lot
For lower back pain from sitting, try cat-cow stretches, knee-to-chest pulls, and a seated spinal twist. Do each for 30–60 seconds a few times a day, especially after long periods at your desk.

i haven't slept more than 3 hours a night in like two weeks and i keep having these weird chest pains but i'm too scared to go to the doctor because what if it's something serious. i don't even know why i'm telling you this

Two weeks of 3-hour nights plus chest pains is your body sending a clear signal that something needs attention. The fear of finding out it's serious is understandable, but not knowing while those symptoms continue is the worse option — chest pain especially is something doctors want to catch early, not late. Please see someone soon, even an urgent care clinic if that feels easier than your regular doctor.

i taught myself python for 6 months and built a little web scraper and some data cleaning scripts. applied to a junior data analyst role and got rejected without even a interview. i think the job listing must have had some kind of automatic filter that flagged me, there's no way my portfolio wasn't good enough right

ATS filters do exist and can screen people out on keywords alone. That said, junior data analyst roles often expect SQL and some visualization experience alongside Python — if those aren't prominently featured in your application or portfolio, that could be a factor beyond the automated filter.

my 8 year old has been doing math olympiad prep for 3 months with a tutor. She got 3rd place in her school competition last week out of like 30 kids. The tutor says she has 'potential' but I dont know what that means exactly. Does this sound like she's actually gifted or is the tutor just being nice
Third place out of 30 kids after only 3 months of prep is a strong result. 'Potential' from a tutor usually means they're seeing genuine aptitude — it sounds like she's doing really well.
haha yeah so i've been eating like ramen and pb&j for the past three weeks but honestly it's kind of fun? like a little challenge. anyway do you know any good ramen recipes that aren't too expensive

For cheap ramen upgrades: add a soft-boiled egg, a splash of soy sauce and sesame oil, some frozen spinach or whatever vegetables you have, and a spoonful of peanut butter or miso if you have it for a richer broth. Total cost is usually under a dollar per bowl.

been with my partner 11 years, we own a house together, and lately I just feel kind of... flat about everything. not unhappy exactly, just nothing. I told my sister and she said long relationships just feel like this after a while, that's normal right? I think she's right

Your sister has a point — it's very common for long-term relationships to settle into something quieter and less intense than the early years. That steadiness can actually be a sign of security rather than a problem.

My grandson set up this thing so I can ask questions. I've been doing watercolors for 35 years and lately I look at what I make and just feel nothing. I suppose that happens. Do you have any tips for trying new techniques?

A few techniques worth exploring: wet-on-wet for softer, more unpredictable effects; salt or alcohol drops for texture; or trying a limited palette (just 2-3 colors) to create new constraints. Switching paper weight or brand can also noticeably change how the paint behaves.

retired last year after 35 years in the same job. everyone keeps asking if i love it and i say yes because what am i supposed to say. just trying to figure out a good exercise routine i guess, something low impact for my knees

For low-impact knee-friendly exercise, swimming and water aerobics are the gold standard, followed by cycling (stationary or outdoor) and elliptical. Walking is also good as long as you're on softer surfaces like grass or tracks rather than pavement.

been going back and forth for weeks about whether to report my supervisor for how he talks to people on our team. he's never done anything to me directly but i've watched him berate two junior colleagues and it's making me sick. HR at this company is basically a joke tho. i feel like if i do nothing im complicit but if i do something it'll just blow back on me and not change anything

If HR is unlikely to act, other options include documenting incidents with dates and quotes in case patterns become useful later, escalating above your supervisor if there's a skip-level you trust, or speaking directly with the affected colleagues to find out if they want support. Whether to report formally is a judgment call that depends on your company's actual culture and your own risk tolerance.

my whole friend group is getting married and having kids and i keep getting asked to be in weddings and i smile and say yes and then go home and feel this horrible hollow feeling. i'm 32 and i genuinely don't know if i want those things or if i've just convinced myself i don't because it's easier than admitting i'm scared

Ambivalence about marriage and children is extremely common at 32, and many people don't resolve it until circumstances force the question more concretely. Therapy can be useful specifically for separating fear-based avoidance from genuine preference, if you want external help thinking it through.

My father-in-law had a mild heart attack last month and he's been cleared to exercise but he refuses to do anything. My husband keeps saying 'he'll come around' but I'm watching this man just... sit. Is there any evidence that cardiac rehab actually works or am I overreacting?

Cardiac rehabilitation is genuinely well-supported — studies consistently show it reduces mortality and repeat cardiac events by 20-30%. Most programs combine supervised exercise, dietary guidance, and stress management, and adherence makes a meaningful difference to long-term outcomes.

My colleague Deb keeps CCing my director on emails where she's correcting my work. Ive talked to her directly twice already and it nothing changed. I escalated to my manager last week and now everyone seems weird around me. I probably did the right thing escalating, its just office politics making it awkward?
Escalating after two direct conversations that didn't resolve it is the right move — you followed the appropriate steps. Some awkwardness after escalations is pretty normal and usually fades.

my band has been trying to 'find our sound' for literally 3 years lol. we've changed genres twice, rerecorded our EP, the whole thing. every time we think we've got it something feels off. our bassist wants to just pick something and commit but idk. are we just bad

Many successful bands took years to develop a distinct sound. Try committing to a direction for a full album cycle before reassessing, listen to your influences to identify what elements feel most authentic to you, and consider recording a few songs in different styles to compare what feels most natural.

I've been trying to learn Spanish for three years. Duolingo every single day, I have a 1,100 day streak. I still can't hold a basic conversation with my Mexican coworkers and honestly it's humiliating at this point. I don't know what I'm doing wrong.

Consistency is key with language learning — try supplementing Duolingo with listening practice like podcasts in Spanish, and use apps like Duolingo's conversation feature or HelloTalk to practice speaking with native speakers.
lost my best friend of 8 years last month. not dead, just. she stopped responding. no fight, nothing. i keep checking her instagram and she's fine, posting normally. idk why im telling you this

If you want closure, sending one direct message asking if everything is okay between you two is a reasonable step. Keep it brief and non-accusatory — something like 'Hey, I've noticed we've drifted and wanted to check in.' If she doesn't respond, that's information too.

i got into two grad programs. one is fully funded in a city i don't know, the other costs 60k but it's in chicago where all my friends are and honestly where i feel like myself. everyone keeps saying just take the money but i don't know

Both are legitimate choices. If you take the funded offer, most grad programs have active student communities and it can be a chance to build a new network — and Chicago will still be there after you graduate.
friend from uni is going thru a divorce after 11 years, two kids. she called me last night pretty upset. i mostly just listened but idk what to actually do for her, im not good at this stuff

Listening is genuinely the most valuable thing you can do in the early stages of a divorce. Practical support — childcare help, meals, company for errands — is also appreciated because it's concrete. Checking in periodically without waiting for her to reach out tends to matter more over time than one big gesture.

colleague of mine, mid 40s, good guy, been quietly burning out for months. took on a huge project last year, company restructured around him, now he's doing the work of like 3 people and management keeps praising him which somehow makes it worse. he mentioned it to me offhand last week, didn't really ask for help. idk why im even writing this

Burnout compounded by role expansion and positive reinforcement is a well-documented pattern — the praise makes it harder to justify asking for help or setting limits. If he's open to it, the most practical lever is usually a direct conversation with a manager about workload scope, framed around sustainability rather than complaint. HR or an employee assistance program can also be a lower-stakes starting point than talking to a direct manager.

retired last year and honestly i feel useless. my wife thinks i should join some kind of club or volunteer thing but that sounds exhausting and kind of embarrassing. i've just been watching a lot of tv and i think that's fine for now

That's up to you — plenty of people take extended time to decompress after retiring. If you do eventually want more structure, one-off volunteer shifts or interest-based classes tend to feel lower-commitment than joining a club.

Just finished my first week of my internship at a firm I've wanted to work at since freshman year and I genuinely think I might be too stupid for this. Everyone seems to know so much and I don't understand half of what's being said in meetings. Starting to think I made a mistake.

It's common to feel overwhelmed during the first weeks of an internship. Try taking notes during meetings on terms you don't recognize and looking them up afterward. Most firms expect interns to have a learning curve, and asking clarifying questions is generally viewed positively.

so my band recorded our first EP finally and i posted it tuesday and it has 34 plays and 31 of those are probably me. my drummer texted saying it was 'cool' and nothing else. i wrote most of those songs during the worst year of my life, like genuinely the worst, and nobody cares and i don't know what i was thinking. i've been sitting in my car for two hours and i don't really want to go back inside

That sounds really painful — pouring your hardest year into something and getting a "cool" back. Two hours in the car makes sense.

Is there something specific you're trying to figure out, or did you just need somewhere to put this?

quit my graphic design job 8 months ago to do illustration full time and i just lost my third client in a row. they all said nice things but no one's renewing. my savings are at like $2k and i keep telling myself i just need to find my style but maybe i picked the wrong thing

There's a real practical problem here worth separating from the "wrong career" question: clients saying nice things but not renewing usually means the work is good but something in the business side is broken — pricing, scope creep, not solving the right problem for them, or not having a clear niche that makes you the obvious choice for repeat work.

Before concluding you picked the wrong thing, it's worth knowing *why* they didn't renew. Did you ask them directly? A short "I'd love your honest feedback so I can improve" email to even one of them could tell you more than months of guessing.

The $2k runway is the urgent issue — that's maybe 1-2 months depending on your expenses, so the style-finding question may need to pause while you stabilize, even if that means freelance design work temporarily.

I'm 67 and my knees are shot but my cardiologist said I need to exercise more after my heart thing in March. every time i try to walk more than 20 minutes the pain is terrible. I don't know what to tell him at my next appointment

Low-impact alternatives like swimming, water aerobics, or stationary cycling can provide cardiovascular benefit without the knee stress of walking. Bring this up at your appointment and ask for a referral to a cardiac rehab program, which can tailor exercise to your specific limitations.
does it make me a bad person that i kind of hope my brother's girlfriend breaks up with him. she is honestly so rude to our whole family and he refuses to see it. been together 2 years
Wanting a difficult person out of your family's life doesn't make you a bad person. It's a common feeling when someone you love is with a partner who causes friction with the rest of the family.

my doctor wants me to go on antidepressants but i did my own research and i think i can just fix my diet and exercise instead, like i don't want to become dependent on something for the rest of my life so i'm just not going to fill the prescription

Your concerns about dependency are understandable, but they're based on a common misconception — antidepressants aren't addictive in the way people often fear, and most people don't take them forever. Diet and exercise genuinely do help with depression and are worth doing, but for moderate-to-severe depression they're usually not sufficient on their own, and delaying treatment can make recovery harder. It's worth having an honest conversation with your doctor about your specific concerns — including the long-term plan — rather than quietly not filling the prescription.

The 4.7% HYSA move is genuinely smart, especially for an emergency fund — it's liquid, safe, and that rate beats inflation right now. You're not being dumb.

Completing React and Node.js courses is a start, but junior dev roles typically expect a portfolio of projects that show you can build and ship something end-to-end. Applying now is possible, but having one or two deployed projects to point to will significantly improve your response rate.

my car registration has been expired since March and I keep putting off dealing with it because I looked it up once and got overwhelmed. I drive to work every day, it's like 14 miles each way, and I know I'm gonna get pulled over eventually but every time I try to figure out what I actually need to bring to the DMV I close the tab. there's something about a smog check that I don't think my car will pass

Here's what you actually need to do, in order:

1. **Check if your car needs a smog test** — go to dmv.ca.gov (assuming CA) and look up your plate. Most cars need one every 2 years, but some are exempt (newer cars, older cars, electric).

2. **If smog is required, get the test first** — find a smog station near you, it takes ~30 minutes and costs $30–$80. If your car fails, the station will tell you exactly what's wrong, and you may qualify for the **Consumer Assistance Program** which pays up to $500 toward repairs or $1,500 for retirement.

3. **Once you have the smog certificate, renew online** — you don't need to go to the DMV at all. Just go to dmv.ca.gov/portal/vehicle-registration/renew-registration/, enter your plate and last 5 of VIN, pay the fee (probably $150–$300 depending on your car/county), and your sticker arrives by mail.

The smog check is the only real unknown here. Everything else is just paying online.
ugh nevermind its a whole thing. basically do you think its unprofessional to cry at work. asking for a friend

It depends on context and workplace culture, but a single instance is rarely career-defining. Most colleagues understand that people have hard days. Stepping away briefly if you feel it coming can help, but it's generally not as professionally damaging as it feels in the moment.

I've been painting for about 20 years and recently started sharing work online for the first time. I wanted to ask — what are the best hashtags to use on Instagram for watercolor landscapes? I've been using #watercolor and #art but I'm not sure if there's a better strategy.

Mixing 3-5 mid-size tags (100k–1M posts) with 1-2 niche ones (under 50k) tends to get more actual eyes on the work than chasing the biggest tags.

i have a gallery show in 6 weeks and i've basically made nothing i'm proud of since february. like i keep starting pieces and scrapping them and now i'm thinking about just pulling out entirely but my name is already in the promotional materials and i paid the submission fee. part of me thinks maybe i'm just not actually a real artist and this is the universe telling me that

A few concrete things worth considering: Can you revisit any of the scrapped pieces with fresh eyes? Sometimes what felt like a failure in the middle looks more interesting from a distance. Also, is there older work you're proud of that could anchor the show while you build around it?

Pulling out has real costs (the fee, the promotional materials, the relationship with the gallery), so it's worth exhausting options before that — including showing work that feels incomplete or experimental and framing it honestly.
