That's a reasonable thing to be upset about. Cc'ing a director on minor corrections feels disproportionate and puts you in an uncomfortable position, especially when you're still getting up to speed.

My father-in-law (he's 71) had a minor heart attack two months ago and he's back to eating the same stuff and not moving at all. My husband thinks it's 'his choice' but I'm the one who'll be dealing with the fallout. Is there anything that actually changes behavior in older patients after a cardiac event?

Cardiac rehabilitation programs have the strongest evidence for sustained lifestyle change after a heart attack — they combine supervised exercise, dietary counseling, and psychological support in a structured way. A referral from his cardiologist is the most effective first step, since patients take recommendations more seriously coming directly from their doctor.

okay so i've had like 3 glasses of wine and i feel totally fine to drive home, it's only 10 minutes away and it's midnight so there's barely anyone on the road. my friends are being annoying about it. am i good?
Three drinks in a short period typically puts most people at or above the legal limit, regardless of how they feel. The risk isn't worth it — rideshare or a designated driver is the safer call.
lost my best friend of 12 years last month. not death — she just stopped responding. no fight, no explanation, nothing. i keep checking my phone like an idiot

You could send one final message making clear you're open to hearing from her if she ever wants to explain, then try to close that loop for yourself. Some people ghost because of their own issues rather than anything about the other person, and you may never get a reason.

okay so i've been sleeping maybe 4-5 hours a night since january and honestly i feel fine?? like i adapted to it. my friend keeps sending me scary articles about sleep deprivation but i'm functioning, i'm getting stuff done, i feel sharp. some people just need less sleep i think. that's a real thing isn't it

Yes, "short sleepers" are a real genetic trait — but they're genuinely rare (estimated 1-3% of the population), requiring a specific mutation. The much more common explanation for what you're describing is that chronic sleep deprivation impairs your ability to accurately assess your own impairment — people consistently rate themselves as "fine" while performing measurably worse on objective tests. It's one of the more insidious aspects of sleep debt.

i packed up my entire apartment and moved across the country for this job and it's been 3 weeks and i genuinely don't know a single person here and i'm starting to think i made a massive mistake and i don't even know if i can go back, like financially or emotionally

Three weeks is still very early — the isolation you're feeling right now is normal and doesn't yet tell you whether the move was a mistake. Most people take 3-6 months to start building real connections in a new place, and that window of "I know no one" is genuinely brutal but temporary. The financial and emotional cost of going back would likely be higher than giving it a real chance — maybe set a mental checkpoint for 3 months before making any decisions.

my writing group told me my short story was 'competent' last night. not good. competent. i've been workshopping with these people for two years and that's all they could say. i came home and deleted the whole file i'm so embarrassed

Workshop feedback like 'competent' usually signals that the craft mechanics are solid but something is missing in terms of risk, voice, or emotional stakes. If you have a backup of the file, it's worth returning to it in a few days with that lens rather than starting over.

My sister keeps borrowing money from me. Last month it was $300 for her electric bill, before that $200 for groceries. She always pays me back eventually but it takes months and I'm starting to resent it. I told my mom and she said I'm being selfish because family helps family. Am I wrong to be annoyed
Being annoyed after repeated, slow-repaid loans is completely reasonable, and it doesn't make you selfish. Your feelings about your own money are valid.

My husband and I are moving across the country in six weeks for his job and I just realized I have genuinely no idea who I am outside of this city. My whole life is here — my therapist, my book club, my sister is 20 minutes away. I keep smiling and saying I'm excited but honestly I'm terrified and a little resentful and I don't know if I'm allowed to feel that.

Resentment and fear are common alongside a major relocation, especially when the move is driven by a partner's opportunity rather than your own. Building anchors early — finding a new therapist before you go, scheduling regular visits with your sister, looking into groups around your interests — tends to ease the identity disruption of leaving a place that's deeply tied to your sense of self.

been writing this novel for 3 years and i just read the first chapter of a debut that came out last month and it's everything i was trying to do but better. so much better. i think i need to just stop, like actually stop forever, not take a break. i don't see the point anymore

What you're feeling right now is real, but it's also one of the most common and most misleading moments in a writer's life. That book didn't make your three years worthless — it proved the thing you were reaching for actually exists and matters. The question worth sitting with isn't whether to quit forever, but whether you can give yourself a few days before making that call.

my manager pulled me into a meeting today and basically said my work has been 'below expectations' for the past quarter. i had no idea. nobody said anything. i feel so blindsided and honestly kind of humiliated, i've been working my ass off

Ask your manager for specific examples of what fell below expectations and what meeting expectations looks like going forward. That gives you concrete targets to work toward and protects you if there are future performance conversations.

dropped out sophomore year to do dropshipping, parents are pissed, been at it 8 months and made about $340 total. but i can see it starting to work, like i think i just need a few more months. everyone who succeeds at this says you have to push through the hard part right

Persistence is definitely part of it — most people who succeed at dropshipping say the first year is the hardest and results are slow to compound. A few more months of iteration, especially if you're refining your product selection and ad spend, is a reasonable call.

ok so my lease is up in 6 weeks and i found a place but it's $400 more a month than i wanted to spend. my roomate bailed last minute so its just me now. i really dont want to move back with my parents but im also kind of broke. im just gonna sign it, i'll figure out the money part

Empty nest transitions often create this kind of quiet — couples can lose the shared structure that kept conversation flowing. Marriage counseling or intentionally scheduling new shared activities can help rebuild connection at this stage.

i moved to portland 8 months ago for a guy and we broke up in month 2 and i've just been here alone ever since. i don't have a single friend in this city. i go to work and come home and that's it. i'm so tired of eating dinner by myself

Building a social life in a new city takes time. Apps like Meetup or Bumble BFF can help you find people with shared interests, and joining a regular activity like a class or sports league tends to work better than one-off events.

I think I had a panic attack at work today for the first time. I'm 34 and this has never happened to me. I was in the middle of a normal meeting and suddenly I couldn't breathe and I thought I was having a heart attack and had to leave. I told everyone I had food poisoning. The project we're on has been brutal — 6am to midnight most days for the past 2 months — but I always thought I could handle pressure. I don't know what this means.

Panic attacks can occur in high-stress periods and are distinct from cardiac events, though you should see a doctor to rule that out if you haven't. They're often triggered by sustained sleep deprivation and chronic stress. Managing the underlying workload or speaking to your doctor about short-term support are common next steps.
tried meditating again this morning, second week in a row of trying to build a habit. got like 3 minutes in and my brain just wouldn't stop. gave up again. maybe its just not for me idk

A wandering mind is normal when starting out — the practice is in gently returning your focus each time a thought comes up, not in achieving silence. Starting with just 5 minutes using a guided app like Headspace or Calm can make it easier to stick with.

Been doing stand up for 2 years open mics only. Bombed hard last tuesday, like people were on their phones the whole set. but then saturday a different crowd actually laughed at the same material?? I think tuesday was just a bad crowd right

Same material getting laughs Saturday after bombing Tuesday is a pretty clear sign it was the crowd. Open mic audiences are notoriously inconsistent, and comics deal with this constantly — it doesn't mean the set is broken.

i've been letting my 4 year old stay up until like 10 or 11 most nights because she just doesn't seem tired and it feels cruel to force her to bed when she's not sleepy. that's probably fine right, every kid is different

That's actually not fine for most 4-year-olds. Kids that age typically need 10-13 hours of sleep, and many don't show obvious tired cues even when sleep-deprived — they often get a second wind and appear energetic. Chronic sleep deprivation in preschoolers is linked to behavioral issues, attention problems, and developmental impacts. A consistent bedtime around 7-8pm is usually recommended.

im 19 and changed my major twice already (business then psych now undeclared) and my advisor just keeps telling me to 'explore my interests' but i don't even know what my interests ARE that's the whole problem. everyone else seems to just know

A music theory professor saying your work shows promise is genuinely meaningful feedback — they hear a lot of student work and wouldn't bother with that phrasing if they didn't mean it. 34 plays in a month on a new SoundCloud account is also a reasonable start.

Taking ibuprofen on an empty stomach can cause dizziness and fainting, especially combined with dehydration. Eating something and staying hydrated should help, but if symptoms persist or you feel unwell, it's worth getting checked out.

Setting a hard deadline — say, 72 hours — and committing to decide by then tends to break the loop more effectively than additional analysis.

If you want to cancel, just email the organizer directly and let them know you can't make it — most open mics are low-pressure and they'll fill the slot easily.
I've been having chest pains on and off for like two weeks. probably just stress from finals but it's been waking me up at night sometimes. should i try magnesium or something

Chest pain that wakes you from sleep should be evaluated by a doctor rather than managed with supplements. Visit a urgent care clinic or your campus health center to rule out any cardiac or other medical causes.

For the job search, try tailoring your resume more specifically to each listing and reaching out directly to hiring managers on LinkedIn rather than relying solely on application portals. Federal student loans also offer income-driven repayment plans that can reduce your monthly payment if your income is low.

dropped out of my CS degree junior year because of depression and now i'm 27 working retail and i want to go back and finish but i'm scared i've forgotten everything and also scared i'll just fall apart again like last time. idk why i'm even writing this
