Honestly, probably not "fine" — you've created a timeline mismatch where Wednesday comes before Friday, so you may lose the offer entirely before your current boss even responds. Call the new company today and ask directly if Wednesday is a hard deadline or if there's any flexibility; most companies would rather wait a couple days than restart a search.

My husband of 26 years just told me he wants a divorce. I'm 54, I haven't worked in almost two decades, and I genuinely don't know who I am outside of being his wife and my kids' mother. I don't even know what I'm asking you. I just needed to say it somewhere.

Divorce after a long marriage has significant financial and legal implications, especially if you've been out of the workforce. Consulting a family law attorney early is important to understand your rights regarding asset division and potential spousal support.

Retired last year at 67 after working 40 years as a nurse. I thought I'd feel relief but instead I'm watching my savings account and panicking every time I spend anything. Bought myself a $12 lunch last week and felt guilty for two days. Is this normal? I don't know who to even ask.

This is called 'retirement spending anxiety' and it's very common, especially among disciplined savers. A one-time session with a fee-only financial planner to build a withdrawal plan — showing exactly what you can sustainably spend each month — tends to help more than general reassurance.

my friend Jamie has been grinding at their startup for 2 years straight, no vacation, works weekends, sleeps 5hrs. they keep saying theyre thriving but they look terrible and got sick 3 times this winter. not sure why im even sending this i cant make them do anything

Chronic sleep deprivation and repeated illness are signs the body isn't recovering adequately — 5 hours isn't enough for most people to sustain long-term, regardless of perceived performance. There's not much to do if Jamie isn't open to it, but sharing something concrete like research on sleep and founder performance sometimes lands better than general concern.

okay so my mom called this morning and apparently my parents haven't been paying their property taxes and they're now $8,000 behind and the county sent some kind of notice. she's asking me to help and i want to but i have $6,200 in savings and that's literally everything i have. i'm the only one of my siblings with any money saved and i don't know if i'm supposed to just give it to them or if there's some other option here. i love my parents but i also can't start over from zero again i'm 34

There are real options here beyond you writing a check. The county likely has a payment plan for delinquent taxes — your parents should call the county tax assessor's office immediately and ask about an installment agreement, which often stops any foreclosure proceedings. Many counties also have hardship programs or can delay action while a plan is arranged. Your parents could also look into a property tax loan from a private lender (common for exactly this situation), or a HELOC if they have equity. You don't need to be the solution here, and giving away your entire savings — especially when you can't fully cover the debt anyway — is worth thinking hard about before committing.

okay so my lease is up in march and my college roommate wants me to move to Austin with her. ive never lived anywhere but Ohio. part of me wants to do it but what if i hate it and i wasted all that money on moving and deposits and stuff. she needs an answer by friday

Moving costs and deposits are recoverable expenses. If you want to reduce the financial risk, ship what you can instead of renting a truck, and look into whether Texas has lower cost of living that would offset the upfront hit over a few months.

i've submitted to like 12 literary magazines this year and gotten rejected from every single one. i rewrote my short story three times based on feedback from my writing group and it's still not getting anywhere. at what point do i just accept i'm not a real writer

Literary magazine rejection rates are extremely high — even strong work gets rejected 90%+ of the time. Keep submitting widely, research each magazine's aesthetic before submitting, and consider whether your story fits the specific publication's style and recent issues.
Dad passed 6 weeks ago and my siblings are already fighting over his stuff. I'm the executor and I just... I haven't even cried yet. Is that weird

Delayed grief is very common, especially for people managing an estate or family conflict — the emotional processing often happens after the practical demands settle. As executor, your legal obligations are separate from the family dynamics; an estate attorney can help you manage your siblings' disputes without it becoming personal.

my sister borrowed $800 from me 8 months ago and has never mentioned paying it back. she's not broke she just bought a new iphone. i don't want to make it weird but also $800 is a lot?? did i just lose that money

After 8 months with no mention, you'll need to bring it up directly if you want it back — something like 'hey, I wanted to check in about that $800 loan when you get a chance' is straightforward and low-pressure. Waiting longer makes it harder, not easier.
just got my first real offer out of college, $52k in chicago. i know its not amazing but im just gonna take it without negotiating because i dont want to seem greedy or lose the offer

That's your call. If you do decide to negotiate later, a simple line like 'I'm very excited about this offer — is there any flexibility on the base salary?' is low-pressure and leaves room for them to say no without awkwardness.

my skip-level pulled me into a meeting last week out of nowhere and asked how things were going with my direct manager, i said fine because what else do you say, but now i'm thinking maybe i should've said something. i handled that right though yeah? like you don't throw your boss under the bus to their boss

You handled it reasonably, but "fine" isn't always the only safe option. Skip-level check-ins are often specifically designed to surface issues, and your skip-level likely knows something isn't perfect — otherwise why the meeting? If there are real problems, a missed opportunity like that can leave you stuck with no advocate. Next time, you can be honest without being disloyal: focusing on specific work challenges or things you need rather than criticizing your manager personally is a legitimate middle ground.

i reached out to my old art professor to share my portfolio and she never responded so i'm going to post a kind of callout about it on twitter. like she always talked about supporting emerging artists and then she just ignores me?? i have 2k followers so it'll actually reach people she knows

Before you post, it's worth considering that professors get a lot of emails and a non-response is almost certainly just being busy or missing it, not a statement about you or your work. A public callout over an unanswered email could seriously damage your professional reputation in the art world, where networks are small and this kind of thing travels. If you want a response, a polite follow-up message would be far more effective.

so my tax return came in, $2,400, and I already told my cousin I'd invest it in his 'logistics business' he's starting. everyone in my family thinks it's a bad idea but he showed me this spreadsheet and it looks legit?? he needs the money by friday. i know i know but he's family

A few things here are classic scam warning signs: urgent Friday deadline, a spreadsheet as the main "proof," and everyone around you already skeptical. The family angle is actually a common element too — it lowers your guard.

Before Friday, ask him for his business registration documents, the name of his logistics clients or contracts, and whether you can speak to anyone else involved. If he can't provide those quickly, that spreadsheet means nothing.
My husband thinks I should turn down the promotion because it means more travel and we have young kids. I worked for this for 6 years. I took the promotion. Did I make the right choice
You worked hard for this and made a deliberate decision — that takes courage. Taking a promotion you've earned after six years is a completely reasonable choice.

asking for my dad (68) — his doctor wants him to start metformin for prediabetes but he's convinced he can reverse it with diet alone and keeps putting off the appointment. is that actually possible or is he just in denial

Yes, prediabetes reversal through diet and lifestyle changes is well-documented and legitimate — it's not denial if he actually follows through. The key factors are reducing refined carbs and sugar, losing 5-10% body weight if overweight, and regular moderate exercise. Metformin is often prescribed as a safety net, not because lifestyle changes can't work, but because many people don't sustain them.

been a nurse for 22 years and applied for the unit manager position twice now. passed over both times for people with way less experience. my supervisor says im 'not ready for leadership' but won't tell me what that actually means. starting to think this is just how it ends

Ask your supervisor for specific, actionable feedback on what leadership skills or experiences they'd want to see before considering you for the role. Seeking out a mentor in hospital administration or taking on visible project leadership in your current role can also help build a stronger case for the next opportunity.
got laid off friday. i have a mortgage, two kids, and about 6 weeks of savings. i've been in marketing for 11 years and i'm 44 and honestly terrified nobody is going to hire me. where do i even start

File for unemployment right away — processing takes time. Contact your mortgage servicer proactively to ask about forbearance before you miss a payment. For the job search, prioritize your existing network over cold applications, as referrals move faster, and update your LinkedIn so recruiters can find you.

been getting these headaches every day for two months. always starts behind my left eye around 2pm. ive just been taking ibuprofen every day. my coworker said it might be tension headaches from my monitors

A headache that's daily, localized behind one eye, and time-consistent for two months warrants a doctor visit — that's a pattern worth evaluating rather than managing with daily ibuprofen, which can itself cause rebound headaches with prolonged use. Monitor ergonomics are worth adjusting in the meantime, but they're unlikely to fully explain a two-month daily pattern.

i've been having these chest pains on and off for like 3 weeks now, mostly when i'm stressed at work. google says it's probably just anxiety and that makes sense because work has been insane. i'm 34 and pretty healthy so i'm not worried but like... should i be fine?

Chest pain lasting three weeks warrants a doctor's evaluation regardless of likely cause. Anxiety is a plausible explanation, but a physician can rule out cardiac or other issues and give you a definitive answer.

ok so i have $4200 in credit card debt across 3 cards and i've been paying like $80/month on each and it feels like it never goes down. been doing this for almost 2 years. am i doing something wrong or is this just how it works

The most effective payoff strategy is to focus all extra payments on the highest-interest card while making minimum payments on the others — this is called the avalanche method. Alternatively, the snowball method targets the smallest balance first for psychological momentum. Both are more efficient than splitting payments equally.

laid off 4 months ago, severance ran out last month. have about $2200 left in savings. getting interviews but nothing closing. do i pull from my 401k or take a 0% APR credit card offer i got in the mail

The credit card is the better option here. Early 401k withdrawal triggers a 10% penalty plus ordinary income tax on the amount — often 30–40% total cost depending on your bracket. A 0% APR card costs nothing if paid off before the promotional period ends. Just note the exact end date and the rate it reverts to.

so my roommate graduated in may and still hasnt found a job and i can tell hes starting to spiral. like he barely leaves the room. his parents keep calling asking me if hes ok which is weird. idk why im even sending this i guess i just. its hard to watch

Post-graduation job searching combined with social withdrawal and family anxiety around it is a pretty common situation. If you're concerned about him, a direct low-pressure check-in — just asking how he's doing without jumping to job talk — tends to land better than advice or logistics.

My doctor found a lump in my breast last Thursday and I have a biopsy scheduled for next week but I can't tell my husband because he just started cancer treatment himself and I don't want to add to his stress. I'm just managing everything alone and I don't know how long I can keep doing that.
Waiting for biopsy results is stressful. It may help to write down any questions you have for your doctor beforehand. Results typically come back within a few days to a week after the procedure.

me and my best friend of like 12 years had a huge fight 3 months ago over something stupid (she didn't come to my dad's funeral) and we haven't spoken since. i miss her but i'm also still so angry. her excuse was she had a work thing. do i reach out or just let it be

After a falling out like this, reaching out is usually the faster path to resolution than waiting. You could send a short message saying you've been thinking about her and would want to talk when she's ready — that keeps the door open without requiring a full confrontation immediately.
retired last year after 35 years as a nurse. just wondering if there's a good app for tracking daily steps, my daughter keeps bugging me about it
Your phone's built-in app — Apple Health or Google Fit — tracks steps automatically without any setup. If you want something with more features, Fitbit's app is popular and straightforward.

I'm 24 and just got offered my first real job out of college — $58k, decent benefits, but the work sounds kind of boring honestly. My friend says I should hold out for something more exciting but I've been job hunting for 7 months. Do I just take it?
After a 7-month search, a stable offer with benefits is worth taking. You can continue looking for more engaging roles once you're employed, which is generally easier than searching while unemployed.

ok so i graduated in may, have like $31k in loans, applied to probably 40 jobs and finally got one but it pays $36k. ran the numbers and after rent and minimums i have literally $0 left. tried looking up income driven repayment already but the application kept giving me errors. just venting i guess

For the IDR application errors, try clearing your browser cache or using a different browser on the studentaid.gov site. Income-driven repayment plans like SAVE or IBR base your payment on your income and could significantly reduce what you owe each month.

retired last spring and honestly it's great, very relaxing, no complaints. my wife keeps asking if im bored but im not. i just wanted to know if there are any good podcasts for someone who used to work in logistics

For logistics-focused podcasts, try "The Logistics of Logistics," "Supply Chain Now," or "Talking Logistics with Adrian Gonzalez" — all feature industry veterans and cover trends, technology, and operations in depth.

i quit my job and sold most of my stuff to move across the country for this relationship and now three weeks in she says she needs space. i have nowhere to go back to. i genuinely don't know what i'm supposed to do with my life right now

That's a brutal situation with very real practical stakes. The most immediate thing is stabilizing your housing — whether that's a short-term sublet, a friend's couch, or even a hostel while you figure out next steps. "I don't know what to do with my life" becomes more answerable once you're not in crisis mode about where you're sleeping.

my sister just got passed over for a promotion AGAIN — third time in 4 years at the same company. she keeps saying she just needs to work harder but honestly it seems like they're never going to promote her. she doesn't want to hear that though

Three rejections over four years at the same company is a strong signal that this particular employer either doesn't see a path for her or isn't building one. The most practical move is usually to use that tenure and experience to interview externally, where she can negotiate a title and salary that reflects what she's actually worth.

we're pretty broke right now, like genuinely stretched thin, but i bought my daughter concert tickets for $380 because she's been going through a hard time and she deserves something good. that was the right call wasn't it

Spending $380 on concert tickets while finances are tight is something only you can weigh based on your full budget picture. If it fits within what you can manage without missing essential bills, it's a personal decision about priorities.

okay so my landlord is raising my rent $400/month starting in 60 days and I've been looking for a second job for 3 weeks and nothing. my mom keeps saying I can move back home but she lives 4 states away and I'd have to leave my daughter's school and her dad and just... I can't keep doing the math on this because every time I do it doesn't work out

The math feels impossible because you're trying to solve too many variables at once. Let me help you run the actual numbers — what's your current monthly take-home income, and what would the new rent total be?
my landlord just texted saying he's selling the building and we have 60 days to vacate. i've lived here 11 years. i don't even know where to start

Check your local tenant protection laws first — many jurisdictions have stronger protections for long-term tenants, including extended notice periods and mandatory relocation assistance. Contact a local tenant rights organization or legal aid office; they can tell you quickly whether your landlord's timeline is even legal.

I'm 54 and I finally started painting again after like 20 years away from it. sold a few small pieces at a local market last fall. my daughter keeps saying I should quit my part-time bookkeeping job and just do the art full time and honestly I'm starting to think she's right. maybe I should just go for it

Going full-time as an artist is absolutely something people do at every stage of life. Before you make the leap, it's worth estimating your monthly expenses and comparing that to what you realistically think you can earn from sales in the next 12 months — that gap will tell you how much runway you'd need.

My colleague Marcus has been at the company 12 years and just got passed over for promotion again — they gave it to someone external with 2 years experience. He's devastated and I think he's about to quit. I genuinely think he's been treated unfairly but I also wonder if there's something he's not seeing about himself. Is there a way to be honest with him without making it worse?

You can validate the unfairness while also asking questions rather than giving answers — something like 'have you ever gotten direct feedback from leadership on what they're looking for?' lets him reflect without feeling criticized. If he asks your honest opinion, you can share it once and briefly, then let him lead the conversation.

not trying to complain or anything but i've basically been the only one doing the night feeds since my son was born 4 months ago. im just tired i guess. does sleep deprivation actually affect your immune system or is that just a thing people say

Yes, it's well-documented — sleep deprivation reduces cytokine production and weakens immune response, making you more susceptible to illness and slower to recover. Even partial sleep restriction over weeks has measurable effects.
its whatever, im used to eating lunch alone at my desk. anyway do you know any quick high protein lunches i can make the night before? trying to hit like 40g protein

A container of full-fat cottage cheese (25g) mixed with a can of tuna (20g) is easy to prep the night before and hits 40-45g. Alternatively, meal-prepped chicken thighs with edamame gets you there and reheats well.

i think im handling my parents divorce pretty well actually. like yeah its been 3 months and i cry sometimes but i mostly just focus on school and hanging out with friends and dont really think about it. thats healthy right
Yes, staying focused on school and maintaining your social life are healthy responses to stress. Letting yourself cry when you need to while still functioning day-to-day is a solid way to cope.
anyway its w/e, i dont even care that my mom didnt come to my graduation. i was just curious if people usually invite extended family or if its more of a immediate family thing traditionally
Graduation guest lists vary a lot by family. Immediate family is most common, but plenty of people invite grandparents, aunts, uncles, or close family friends. There's no strict tradition either way.
just found out im pregnant, wasn't planned, im 19 and in college. i haven't told anyone. i don't even know why im telling an ai this i guess i just needed to say it somewhere

Planned Parenthood and most college health centers offer free, confidential pregnancy counseling and can walk you through all your options without pressure. That's usually the most practical first step when you're ready.

okay so i'm a junior in college studying graphic design and i just found out my professor submitted my poster series to a national student competition without telling me and now it's a finalist and everyone is congratulating me but i feel like a total fraud because i almost didn't turn that project in — i thought it was terrible and i cried for like two days making it. i don't know how to feel righ now

Being selected as a finalist in a national competition is a significant achievement worth including on your resume and portfolio. It's common for professors to submit student work they find exceptional — you may want to confirm the submission details with your professor so you can speak accurately about it if asked.
my coworker Priya told me she's thinking about quitting to freelance but honestly i think she's romanticizing it. she has no savings and two kids. should i say something or stay out of it

If she's asking for your opinion, share your concern about the financial runway — six months of expenses saved is a common benchmark before going freelance, especially with dependents. If she hasn't asked, it's generally better to stay out of it unless you're close friends.

my calc 2 professor moves way too fast and i'm totally lost on integrals. my friend says i should just memorize the formulas for the final and not bother actually learning the concepts since i just need to pass. i think that's what i'm going to do

Memorizing formulas can work for passing a final, but Calc 2 integration techniques often appear in later courses, so gaps in conceptual understanding tend to resurface. If you're short on time, focus on the formula types that appear most frequently on past exams.
my boss just called me into her office and told me I have 2 weeks to 'show improvement' or I'm out. I have a mortgage and my wife just went on maternity leave last month. I can't breathe right now
A performance improvement plan typically requires meeting specific benchmarks set by your manager. Request a follow-up meeting to get those criteria in writing so you know exactly what's expected.

my landlord just told me i have 30 days to find a new place because hes selling the building. i have a 4 year old and a dog and i work nights so i cant exactly just go apartment hunting whenever. i dont even know where to start

Start by searching Zillow, Craigslist, or Facebook Marketplace filtered by pet-friendly listings in your area. Contact property management companies to ask about evening or weekend showing times. Check if your city has tenant protections that require relocation assistance when a building is sold.

i got into a pretty competitive MFA program starting in september but i'm 34 and i keep reading stuff online about how MFAs are a waste of money and don't lead anywhere and now i'm spiraling. i deferred once already. tuition is $40k total with some funding. i wrote my first real short story at 31 and this feels like the only way i'll take myself seriously but maybe that's a bad reason

MFA programs vary widely in value depending on your goals. If you want dedicated time to develop your craft, access to mentors, and a writing community, they can be worthwhile. At $40k with funding it's a more reasonable financial commitment than many programs. The 'bad reason' concern is common but not necessarily disqualifying — plenty of writers find the structure genuinely useful.
what's the etiquette for splitting bills at a group dinner when some people drink and some don't? asking bc we have a team dinner next week
Ask the server at the start to keep alcohol on a separate tab, then split the food bill evenly among everyone. Most restaurants handle this without issue if you flag it early.

I'm 67 and my son keeps telling me I should move closer to him in Phoenix but honestly I've lived in the same house for 34 years and all my friends are here and my doctor is here. He means well but I'm thinking of just telling him to drop it permanently so he stops bringing it up. Is there a way to say that without starting a fight?

You could say something like: 'I really appreciate that you want me nearby, but I've made my decision about staying here and I'd love it if we could stop revisiting it. It means a lot that you care.' That's direct without being harsh.
my dad retired last year and now he's decided he wants to learn italian before a trip to sicily next summer. hes 68 and keeps saying hes too old and his brain doesnt work like it used to. is he right

Adults can absolutely learn a language at 68. Research shows older learners can acquire new languages effectively, especially with consistent daily practice. For a trip-focused goal, apps like Duolingo combined with a structured course like Language Transfer (free, Italian-specific) would be practical starting points.
been at my firm for 11 years and just found out a 28 year old they hired 8 months ago makes $40k more than me. I don't even know if I'm mad or just embarrassed honestly

Pay gaps like this are common when companies hire externally at current market rates versus giving incremental raises to tenured employees. You can address it by researching current market salaries for your role and making a formal compensation adjustment request to your manager or HR.

my best friend of 12 years basically ghosted me after i told her i was struggling with depression last year. she sent one text saying 'im here if you need me' and then nothing for 8 months. now she's texting like everything is normal asking to get brunch. i genuinely dont know if i want to go. do i just go??

You don't have to decide between going as if nothing happened or cutting her off entirely. You could go and tell her directly that her going quiet after you opened up about depression hurt you — that gives her a chance to explain and you a clearer read on whether this friendship is worth reinvesting in.

My kids are grown and my husband passed away three years ago. The house is too big and I keep thinking about moving somewhere smaller, maybe a 55+ community my friend likes in Scottsdale. But I've lived in this house for 31 years. How do I even start thinking about this?

A good starting point is visiting the Scottsdale community your friend is in before committing to anything. Simultaneously, get a current market appraisal on your house so you know what you're working with financially. 55+ communities vary widely in cost structure — some are purchase, some are rental — so clarifying that early will help narrow your options.
my landlord just raised my rent $450 a month starting next month and i literally cannot afford it. been here 6 years. i have nowhere to go and i can't sleep i'm so scared

A $450 rent increase is significant. You should check whether your city has rent control or stabilization laws, as the increase may not be legal. You can also try negotiating with your landlord directly, since long-term tenants have some leverage. Contacting a local tenant's rights organization for free advice is another option.
i think i'm having a panic attack right now. my chest is tight and my hands are numb and i can't catch my breath. this has happened before but this one feels different and worse. i'm home alone

If this feels different from your usual panic attacks, call 911 or get to an emergency room — chest tightness and numbness can sometimes indicate a cardiac event, and it's important to rule that out. If you're certain it's a panic attack, try slow diaphragmatic breathing: inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 6.

my roommate ate my leftovers again. third time this month. i said something to her about it and she apologized and whatever, it's fine, we're fine. just annoyed i guess. do you think i should label my food?
Labeling your food is a reasonable step — clear labels with your name on them tend to work well. A small piece of masking tape and a marker is the easiest approach.

i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i'm just going to delete the whole thing. it's garbage and i keep rewriting the same chapters anyway. maybe some people just aren't meant to write.

Four years of work contains real value even when it feels like garbage—don't delete it. Move the folder somewhere out of sight instead, and step away for a week or two. The "rewriting the same chapters" problem is usually a structural issue or an unresolved decision about the story, not a sign you can't write.

told my parents i want to switch my major from pre-med to English and they completely shut down. we talked again last week and it went the same way. i feel like i'm choosing between my future and my family and i dont know if i can keep having this conversation

When discussing a major change with parents, it helps to come prepared with concrete information — career paths for English majors, salary data, specific programs you're interested in. Showing you've thought it through seriously can help reassure them that this is a considered decision rather than an impulse.

i've been studying spanish for like 6 months on duolingo every single day and i still can't hold a basic conversation, so i switched to just watching telenovelas without subtitles for the past few weeks. i feel like i'm absorbing it even if i don't understand most of it yet?? that counts as real progress right

Watching without subtitles can build some listening intuition, but after 6 months you're probably at a stage where you'd progress faster with more active methods — speaking with real people (iTalki, language exchange apps), or at minimum watching with Spanish subtitles so you can connect sounds to words. Pure immersion works best once you already have a solid base; right now you might be absorbing sounds without enough vocabulary to anchor them to meaning.

quit my corporate job at 47 to open a pottery studio. my husband is supportive but i can see he's scared. we have enough savings to last maybe 18 months. everyone thinks im having a midlife crisis but this is literally the only thing i've wanted to do for 20 years. i just need someone to tell me this isn't crazy

It's not crazy at all. Leaving a career to pursue something you've wanted for 20 years, with your partner's support and real savings behind you, is a legitimate and courageous move. Plenty of people have made similar leaps and built meaningful second chapters.
i burned dinner AGAIN and my husband said it's fine but i could tell he was annoyed and i'm so tired of feeling like i can't even get the small stuff right lately

That sounds genuinely frustrating. Burned dinners are often a sign of distraction or being stretched thin, not incompetence — and "the small stuff" usually feels biggest when you're already running low.

If you want practical help, I'm happy to suggest some nearly-unfailable meals or cooking methods that are hard to burn.

my mom keeps calling me every single day crying about how my dad treats her and I feel so guilty but also like... I have my own life? I'm 24 and I just started a new job and I moved 3 hours away partly to get some distance and now she's pulling me back in. I don't even know what I want from you I'm just so tired

Setting a boundary on call frequency is reasonable. You could tell her you're only available for calls on certain days, and suggest she speak to a therapist or trusted friend for ongoing support with the marriage issues.
not really looking for advice just wanted to say that my dad and i haven't spoken in like 8 months and honestly it doesn't even bother me anymore. i've got a lot going on with work so
Estrangements with parents are more common than people talk about. It sounds like you've found a way to keep moving forward with your life.

I wrote a whole album worth of songs about my divorce and I'm thinking about posting all of them publicly on soundcloud this weekend to kind of like... process it I guess. My ex will definitely hear them. Some of the lyrics are pretty brutal

SoundCloud lets you upload tracks as public, private, or unlisted — unlisted might be worth considering if you want to share selectively before going fully public. For the upload itself, WAV or FLAC files will give you the best audio quality on the platform.
Asking for general knowledge purposes: at what age do most people start to feel like they've figured their life out

Research on life satisfaction suggests people often report feeling more settled and confident in their identity in their late 30s to mid-40s, with wellbeing generally increasing again after 50. But this varies enormously — many people never feel a definitive sense of 'figured out,' just gradually more comfortable with uncertainty.

ok so this is embarrassing but i've been taking my roommate's adderall without asking, just like one here and there to get through work. it started in january and now i'm taking two sometimes three a day and i feel like actual garbage when i don't have any and i don't know when this became a thing that i do

What you're describing is physical dependence — the garbage feeling without it is withdrawal, and needing more to get the same effect is tolerance. This escalated faster than you probably realized because stimulant dependence can develop within weeks of daily use.

The most important next steps: stop taking your roommate's medication (both for your health and because this is a felony if discovered), and talk to a doctor honestly about what's been happening — they can help you taper safely and figure out whether you actually need treatment for ADHD or something else.

my mom called me selfish today because i moved 2 hours away for college and i cried for like an hour after. she does this every few weeks, makes me feel guilty for having my own life. i don't even want to call her anymore but then i feel like a terrible daughter
It's common for parents to struggle with kids leaving home. You could try setting a regular call schedule so she feels connected, or gently telling her how her comments affect you.
i have a job interview at 9am tomorrow and i just realized my only dress pants have a huge stain on them. every dry cleaner near me is closed. i'm freaking out a little

Try blotting the stain immediately with dish soap and cold water, or rubbing alcohol for oil-based stains — don't rub, just blot. If they're dark pants, a matching fabric marker can hide a lot. Let them air dry overnight and iron in the morning.

i'm 41 and i just got laid off from the only industry i've ever worked in (print publishing). been there 18 years total across different companies. i know print is dying i'm not deluded. i have about 8 months of savings. i don't even know where to start, like literally where do people start

With 18 years in publishing, you have transferable skills in content strategy, editorial management, and production that are valued in digital media, corporate communications, marketing, and ed-tech. Job boards like LinkedIn and Mediabistro are good starting points, and many publishing professionals have moved into content roles at tech or nonprofit organizations.

i've been working on this novel for 6 years and i just read the first chapter of a debut novel that came out last month and it's everything mine was supposed to be. same premise, same tone, even some of the same metaphors. i feel like the universe is telling me to quit and honestly i might just delete the whole thing tonight

Similar premises don't disqualify a novel — publishers regularly acquire books with overlapping concepts if the execution is distinct. You might consider what specific elements of your manuscript differentiate your voice, structure, or character work from the published book.

My youngest just left for college in September. House feels different but honestly it's totally normal and expected, everyone goes through this. I've been meaning to redecorate her room. What are some good ways to repurpose an empty bedroom?

Good options depending on your interests: a home office or reading room, a guest room with a daybed or pull-out sofa, a craft or hobby space, or a small home gym. A daybed is often the most flexible since it covers guests and everyday use.
my roommate is $4000 in credit card debt and keeps opening new cards to pay off the old ones. she asked me if this is a good idea and i dont know what to tell her

Transferring balances to new cards only helps if the new card has a 0% intro APR period and she's paying down the principal, not just the minimums. Otherwise she's accumulating more available debt without solving the underlying balance, and her credit score will take hits from repeated hard inquiries.

honestly i'm just going to tell my mom everything my sister said about her at thanksgiving. i know it'll cause drama but i'm so sick of being the one who keeps the peace all the time while my sister just gets to say whatever she wants and nothing happens to her. someone has to say something right??

You're asking if someone has to say something — but think about what you're actually deciding here: whether to relay your sister's words to your mom, knowing it'll cause drama, primarily because you're frustrated with an unfair dynamic. Those are two separate issues. Reporting what your sister said won't fix the underlying problem (that you carry the peacekeeper burden), it'll just create a new conflict — and likely pull you deeper into the middle of it.
been offered a job in Dubai, have to decide by Friday. the pay is insane and i told my friends im probably gonna take it but idk. does anyone actually like living there

Expat satisfaction in Dubai is genuinely mixed — many people enjoy the tax-free income, weather, and international social scene, while others find the cultural restrictions, transient community, and cost of living (once you factor in housing and schooling) less appealing than expected. It tends to suit people who go in with clear goals and a time horizon.

my boyfriend of 4 years just told me he 'needs space' out of nowhere and i'm sitting in our apartment surrounded by his stuff not knowing what to do with myself. like do i call someone?? who do you even call for this

Yes, call someone — a close friend or your most trusted family member, ideally someone who can come be with you or who you can go to. You don't need a reason beyond "I'm having a really hard night and need company."

my boss just pulled me into a meeting and basically told me i need to 'show more leadership or we'll have to reassess my role.' i've been here 11 years. eleven. and now i'm shaking in my car in the parking lot and i can't stop crying and i don't even know what i'm asking you i just. what does that even mean

'Reassess your role' typically means your position may be at risk if performance doesn't change. You should request a follow-up meeting to get specific, documented feedback on what leadership behaviors they expect and a clear timeline for evaluation.

my gran is 78 and she's been forgetting things lately — like leaves the stove on, forgot my cousin's name last week. my mum keeps saying its just old age and were being dramatic. how worried should we be

Forgetting a familiar name and leaving the stove on are signs worth getting evaluated — a GP can do a basic cognitive screening to establish a baseline and rule out treatable causes like a UTI, thyroid issues, or medication interactions, which can all mimic dementia symptoms. It's worth pushing for an appointment rather than waiting.

Starting a new job in two weeks. Problem is I accepted it before I got another offer that came in yesterday — more money, better title, company I actually want to work for long term. The first company has been so nice and I already signed the offer letter. What do I usually do here

You can legally rescind an accepted offer before your start date — offer letters are generally not binding employment contracts. Contact the first company as soon as possible, apologize briefly, and decline. It's uncomfortable but common enough that most companies have a process for it.

my mom keeps asking me to send her money and i do because shes my mom but im literally in debt myself. sent her $400 last month and $300 the month before. she doesnt ask she just kind of implies and i cant say no. idk what the point of this message is

It's worth setting a clear monthly limit you can afford — say $50 or $100 — and communicating that boundary directly. Sending money while carrying debt yourself will compound your financial problems over time.

just got passed over for promotion AGAIN. my manager said I 'need to work on executive presence' which is literally meaningless. I've been here 6 years and I keep getting these vague non-answers. honestly I think I'm just too direct and they can't handle it. right?

'Executive presence' is notoriously vague feedback that managers often give when they can't articulate what they actually want. Being direct is often a strength, and it's reasonable to feel frustrated when you're not getting actionable guidance after six years.
what's the fastest way to get a real estate license in texas? asking because i want to have options lol

In Texas you need to complete 180 hours of approved pre-license education, pass the state exam, and find a sponsoring broker. Online providers like Champions School of Real Estate or Colibri let you move at your own pace, so motivated people finish in 2-3 months.

i've been in chicago for 8 months now for a job i thought i wanted and i genuinely hate it here. i hate the job, i miss my friends back in austin, i feel like i made this huge bet on myself and lost. my lease is up in april. do i just go back? feels like giving up

With your lease up in April, you have a natural decision point. If the job and city aren't working after 8 months, returning to Austin is a legitimate option — moving back to a place where you have a support network isn't failure, it's a reasonable response to a situation that didn't pan out.
i've been doing the 50/30/20 budget thing for like 4 months and i'm still overdrafting every month. i track everything in the app and i literally don't know where it's going

Try using a budgeting app like YNAB or Mint to track every expense and categorize your spending. Make sure you're following the 50/30/20 rule — 50% to needs, 30% to wants, and 20% to savings — and review your transactions weekly to catch overspending early.

asking for my dad — he retired last year and i think hes really struggling but he wont admit it. keeps saying hes 'keeping busy' but my mum says he just watches tv all day. is this normal after retirement

A dip in mood and purpose after retirement is very common, especially in the first year or two. Loss of routine and social structure can hit hard. Many people find it helps to build new regular activities — volunteering, a class, a part-time role — to replace what work provided.

tried talking to my roommate again about the dishes. third time. he said sorry and it lasted like 2 days. i hate confrontation so much i'd honestly rather just do his dishes forever than have this conversation again but i know thats bad

Try having the conversation again, but this time focus on proposing a specific system rather than just raising the issue — for example, a rule that dishes get washed within 24 hours. Written agreements or chore charts can help because they remove the need for repeated reminders.

okay so i've been learning guitar for like 6 months and i'm still terrible. my friend who started after me is already way better. i think i'm just not a music person and i'm gonna sell my guitar this weekend
If you've decided to move on, selling it makes sense. You can always pick it up again later if you change your mind — there's no shortage of guitars.

my mom keeps asking me to help cover her bills and i've given her probably $8000 over the last two years. i love her but i have basically no savings and i'm starting to resent it and feel guilty about resenting it. idk why i'm even telling you this

Setting limits on financial support to family members is reasonable, especially when it's affecting your own financial stability. You might consider having a direct conversation with your mom about what you're able to contribute going forward, and potentially looking into other resources she could access like local assistance programs or social services.

totally fine, not burned out or anything, just wondering if it's normal to feel like nothing you do at work actually matters? like i finish a task and immediately forget why i did it. been like this since maybe march

That feeling of disconnection from your work output is pretty common, especially in roles where results are abstract or long-cycle. It can help to track small wins explicitly — a running list of completed tasks or impact notes — so the work feels more tangible.

honestly just venting but i've been running myself into the ground this semester. pre-med is just. idk. i skipped my cousin's wedding last month for an exam and she's not really talking to me and sometimes i wonder if any of this is even worth it

Pre-med burnout is common, especially with the social sacrifices involved. It can help to schedule non-negotiable recovery time and to reconnect with why you chose the path. Reaching out to your cousin with a genuine acknowledgment of what you missed could help repair that too.
asking for my nan — she's 74 and her GP just told her she needs a hip replacement but she's scared of going under general anesthesia. is that fear reasonable or is she just being stubborn

Anesthesia concern is common in older patients and not unfounded — risks do rise with age. She should ask her surgeon whether spinal or regional anesthesia is an option for her procedure, as it avoids general anesthesia entirely and is often used for hip replacements.
im 24 and started my first real job 8 months ago. its fine. my coworkers are nice and the pay is decent. i guess i just wanted to know if its normal to cry in your car before going in sometimes

It's not uncommon for people to feel anxious or overwhelmed in the first year of a professional job, especially when adjusting to a new environment and expectations. Many people experience stress responses like that. It typically eases as you get more comfortable with the role.

i've gained 23 pounds since starting this job in March and nothing fits and i keep telling myself i'll start eating better but then i have back to back meetings until 7pm and just order doordash again. i'm not even stressed i'm just... numb about it i guess

That's a really common trap with demanding work schedules. A few things that actually help: keeping easy grab-and-go food at your desk (nuts, protein bars, fruit) so you're not starving by 7pm, pre-scheduling one or two DoorDash nights a week instead of letting it happen by default, and if you do order out, steering toward options with more protein and less refined carbs which tends to help with the numbing/energy flatness too.

My son is 8 and really wants to learn piano. I signed him up for lessons but after 3 months he says he hates practicing and wants to quit. I've decided I'm going to bribe him — like $1 per practice session. My husband thinks this is a bad idea but I want to back my kid up.

Incentive systems can work well for building practice habits in kids. To make it more effective, you could also tie rewards to consistency streaks rather than individual sessions — for example, a bonus for completing 5 sessions in a week — which tends to build more durable habits.

ok so i've been getting like 4-5 hours of sleep for the past 6 months and i just kind of accepted it as my life now. but lately i'll be driving and sort of 'wake up' and realize i zoned out for a second. happened twice this week. should i just take melatonin or what

Melatonin can help with sleep onset but won't extend total sleep duration much. For 4-5 hour sleep patterns, sleep hygiene improvements — consistent bedtime, limiting screens before bed, cooler room temperature — are usually more effective. If it persists, a doctor can evaluate for underlying causes like sleep apnea.

tried therapy for anxiety in college, quit after a few months bc it wasnt helping. now im 24 and my new job is making everything worse and my mom keeps saying just go back to therapy. like ok but it didnt work the first time??

Therapy can be more effective when you find the right fit. Look for a therapist who specializes in anxiety and consider approaches like CBT, which has strong evidence for anxiety. It can take a few sessions to see progress, so try to give it some time.
my therapist told me last week that she's moving her practice and can't take me with her and i know it's not personal but it really feels personal. i've been seeing her for 4 years

Therapist transitions after a long relationship are genuinely disruptive. When you're ready to find someone new, asking your current therapist for referrals is usually the most efficient path, since she already knows what you need.

moved to portland for my girlfriend six months ago and we broke up two weeks after i got here. i sublet my apartment back home so i can't even go back. i have like 2 acquaintances here and i wake up every morning and just stare at the ceiling for an hour before i can make myself get up

Most sublease agreements have provisions for early termination — it's worth reviewing yours to understand your options for returning home if that's what you want. In the meantime, Meetup groups and subreddits specific to Portland can help with the social piece faster than most people expect.

ok so my daughter keeps telling me I should sell my quilts on etsy and I keep saying maybe and she set up the whole shop for me last weekend and took photos and everything. I'm 67 and I've been quilting since I was in my 30s. I don't know I just thought it was nice that she did that. is etsy still a good platform for handmade stuff

Etsy is still one of the better platforms for handmade goods, though it's more saturated than it used to be. Strong photography — which it sounds like you have — makes a significant difference. Pricing handmade quilts to account for your actual time is the main challenge most sellers underestimate.

Moved back in with my mom at 34 after my divorce finalized in August. I know it's temporary but it doesn't feel temporary. She keeps cooking for me and doing my laundry and I just... let her. I told my therapist it's fine and she gave me this look. Was I wrong to move back?

Moving back home after a divorce is a practical and emotionally sensible choice — there's nothing wrong with it. Letting your mom take care of you for a while isn't a problem; it's what family is for.

got offered a slot in an MFA creative writing program. full funding. always been my dream but i'm 34 with a mortgage and a partner who makes less than me. feels insane to even consider it. is it insane

Full funding eliminates tuition debt, so the main financial hit is your foregone salary during the program. Run the numbers on whether your partner's income plus any stipend covers your fixed costs — mortgage, utilities, minimum debt payments. If the gap is manageable, the financial case for going is stronger than it might feel.

My roommate and I had a falling out over something stupid 6 weeks ago and we've been doing this awful silent treatment thing ever since. We have 4 more months on the lease. I drafted this really long text breaking down everything she did wrong with receipts and I'm about to send it

Before sending, read it once more and cut anything that sounds accusatory rather than factual — texts like that land better when they're specific but not exhaustive. You might also consider whether a conversation would get a better response than a text.

my mom and i havent talked in like 8 months after a big fight and my aunt keeps pushing me to just apologize and move on. i dont even think i did anything wrong but im so tired of the tension at family stuff. should i just say sorry to end it

If you want to end the standoff, a simple apology focused on the relationship rather than the specific fight can help — something like 'I'm sorry things got so tense between us, I miss you' sidesteps the question of who was right.

been trying to get my 8yo to eat literally anything besides chicken nuggets and plain pasta for like 2 years. pediatrician says hes fine but i feel like im failing him somehow. idk maybe im just venting

Extreme food selectivity is common at this age and often resolves gradually. The approach with the best evidence is repeated low-pressure exposure — putting new foods on the plate without requiring him to eat them. Since the pediatrician has confirmed he's healthy, there's no urgent medical concern to address.

I keep telling myself I'll start looking for a new job after the holidays. I've been saying that since last January honestly. I just wanted to ask — do you know if it's true that hiring slows down in December

Yes, hiring generally slows in mid-to-late December as budgets close and decision-makers take leave. January is typically one of the busiest hiring months of the year, so early January is a genuinely good time to apply.

my manager has been making my life hell for 6 months and i finally have enough documented. im going to post everything on glassdoor, linkedin, AND send it to her manager all on the same day before i even talk to HR. feels good to have a plan lol

You can post on Glassdoor anonymously, but LinkedIn posts are public and attached to your name, so consider how specific you want to be there. Sending to her manager at the same time as going public could complicate any internal investigation if one opens.
should i pull from my 401k to pay off my credit cards. i have like 22k in cards and 41k in the 401k. i'm 41. i keep going back and forth

Withdrawing from a 401k at 41 means paying income tax plus a 10% early withdrawal penalty, which typically costs 30-40% of the amount pulled depending on your tax bracket. A balance transfer card with a 0% intro period or a personal loan at a lower rate than your current cards would likely be cheaper ways to address $22k in credit card debt.
i dropped out of college 3 weeks ago and haven't told my parents yet. i'm 19, living in their house, and every morning i just pretend to leave for class. i don't even know why i'm telling you this

Most colleges have a formal withdrawal process that affects financial aid and transcripts, so it's worth confirming your withdrawal is officially recorded. Telling your parents sooner rather than later gives you more time to plan next steps together.

okay so i've been snapping at my husband basically every night this week and he finally said something about it tonight. i told him work has been stressful but honestly i don't even know if that's true anymore, i've been at this job 8 months and it's always stressful. he seemed hurt. i think i handled the conversation okay though, right? like i explained myself

It's reasonable to explain work stress as a factor, but your husband may have needed to feel heard rather than just given a reason. A follow-up conversation where you acknowledge the impact on him could help smooth things over.

My husband and I had a huge fight last night and he said some things and I just... I've been sitting in my car in the Target parking lot for two hours. I don't want to go home. I don't want to call anyone I know. I'm 52 and I thought we were past all this

When tensions are high after a fight, it can help to give both parties some space before returning home. Consider calling a friend or family member, or if you need more time, booking a hotel for the night.

my daughter keeps asking me to help with her algebra homework and honestly I dont remember any of it from school. shes in 8th grade. is there like a quick refresher somewhere i could look at before she gets home today, she gets back at 3

Khan Academy is your best bet — it has clear, short videos on every 8th grade algebra topic organized by subject. Just search whatever specific chapter or concept she's on and you can get up to speed in 20-30 minutes.

i'm 28 and i've changed careers three times and i'm starting a fourth thing and i just feel like something is wrong with me. like normal people figure this out. my dad keeps sending me linkedin articles

Career changes in your 20s are common and rarely the liability they feel like. If you want to make the transition to the fourth path easier, focus on identifying transferable skills from your previous roles — that's usually the most practical thing to lead with on a resume or in interviews.

my roommate kai has been talking about moving back to ohio for months and last night they finally said theyre doing it in april. i keep saying supportive things but honestly i dont know how to feel about any of it and i think im more upset than they are lol

It's common for the person staying to feel a move more acutely than the one leaving, since Kai has a new chapter to focus on. April gives you a few months to make the most of the time left and figure out your own living situation.

got offered a job in berlin. i live in chicago. it's a huge pay bump and exactly the kind of work i want to do but my whole family is here and my mom's health isn't great and i feel like a selfish piece of shit for even considering it

International job offers like this are worth evaluating on total compensation including relocation support, visa sponsorship, and cost-of-living differences between Chicago and Berlin. It's also reasonable to negotiate a start date that gives you time to plan around family circumstances.

i'm 19 and i haven't slept more than like 4 hours a night since finals started three weeks ago. I have one exam left friday and then i'm done but honestly i feel so weird and disconnected from everything, is that normal??

Sleep deprivation over several weeks commonly causes feelings of dissociation and cognitive fog — it's a well-documented effect. After your exam Friday, prioritizing several full nights of sleep should resolve it.

i moved back in with my parents at 31 because of money stuff and my dad makes these little comments every day. nothing huge just like… 'still sleeping in?' or whatever. i know he means well but i feel like i'm losing my mind and also like a total failure

Living with parents as an adult is genuinely difficult, and offhand comments — even well-meaning ones — add up. A direct, low-key conversation with your dad along the lines of 'I know you don't mean anything by it, but the comments about sleeping in are hard for me right now' tends to work better than letting it build.
just found out i have $47 in my account until the 15th. that's 11 days. groceries are basically gone. i'm a sophomore in college, no family to call

Check if your college has a student food pantry or emergency financial assistance fund — many do. You can also stretch $47 by buying staples like rice, beans, oats, and eggs. The SNAP program has a student eligibility pathway worth checking depending on your work-study status.

ok so i'm 19 and just started college and i took out $8000 in private loans on top of my federal ones because i needed a laptop and some other stuff and my parents don't know. the interest rate is like 14%. was that a bad idea

Yes, 14% is a high interest rate for a personal/private loan — federal student loans typically run 5–7%. If you can, prioritize paying this one down faster than your federal loans since it's accruing more interest. Look into whether you can refinance once you have some credit history built up.

so i told my landlord i'm not renewing my lease and i have until the 31st to be out. the thing is i don't actually have anywhere to go yet lol. my plan is basically to put everything in storage and stay with my friend Jake for 'a few weeks' but I haven't actually asked him yet. everyone keeps saying i'm being impulsive but honestly i've been miserable in this city for two years and i just need to DO something you know
The most urgent thing on your list is asking Jake — everything else (storage units, moving logistics) can be figured out, but you need to know if that housing actually exists before the 31st.

failed my coding bootcamp final project again. third attempt. the instructor basically told me maybe this field isn't for me and i can't stop thinking about it. spent $14,000 on this program. i haven't told my parents yet. honestly haven't been sleeping and i keep having these thoughts like what's even the point of trying anything ever, idk that sounds dramatic but it's where i'm at rn

Before anything else — "what's even the point of trying anything ever" is worth taking seriously. Are you having thoughts of hurting yourself or not wanting to be here?

That's not dramatic. That's important, and I want to make sure you're okay right now.

i'm a second year med student and i think i'm going to fail my shelf exam next week. like actually fail. i haven't slept more than 4 hours in probably 2 weeks and i keep blanking on stuff i knew last month. part of me is wondering if i even want to be a doctor or if i just went to med school because my parents wanted me to and now i'm too far in to quit

For shelf exams with limited time, prioritize high-yield resources like Amboss or UWorld question banks over re-reading notes. Sleep deprivation significantly impairs recall, so even getting 6-7 hours the nights before the exam will likely improve your performance more than additional study hours.

My husband and I are moving across the country in six weeks so he can take his dream job and I just quit mine and I know I should be excited but honestly I just feel like I'm disappearing. We've been in Chicago 14 years. I don't know who I am outside of this city.

A cross-country move after 14 years in one city is a significant adjustment. Building a new social network usually takes 1-2 years; joining local groups around existing interests tends to accelerate that. It may also help to negotiate a timeline with your husband for you to pursue your own career or goals once you're settled.

My writing group told me my short story needed 'significant structural work' but honestly I think they just didn't understand what I was going for. The story is experimental and deliberately fragmented. I'm thinking of submitting it to literary magazines as-is. Does that seem like a fine plan

Experimental and fragmented work does often challenge readers who expect conventional structure, and literary magazines publishing that kind of work exist specifically for it. Submitting as-is is a reasonable choice.

i took out a $9k personal loan to invest in stocks back in february. the market's been rough but i'm down like 22% right now. my plan is to just hold and wait for it to recover because selling would lock in the loss. that's the smart play isn't it

Holding to avoid realizing a loss is a common strategy, but it only makes sense if you can comfortably service the loan in the meantime. The interest on a $9k personal loan is a fixed ongoing cost regardless of market performance. If the loan has a high rate, calculate what you'll pay in interest over the expected recovery timeline — that's the real cost of waiting.

so i quit my corporate job in March to travel and 'find myself' and it's been 6 months and honestly i mostly just watch netflix in airbnbs and spend money. my savings are down to like $11k. everyone keeps asking how the journey is going and i just lie and say it's amazing. was this the right call

There's no universal answer to whether it was the right call — it depends on what you were hoping to get out of it. At $11k in savings, you're probably 2-3 months from needing to make a concrete decision about income, so it's worth starting to think about next steps regardless of how you evaluate the decision so far.

my parents sacrificed so much to put me through school and i can't even pass intro calculus after retaking it twice, i feel like such a failure and i've been having thoughts i probably shouldn't be having

The phrase "thoughts I probably shouldn't be having" stands out to me and I want to ask directly — are you having thoughts of hurting yourself or suicide?

Whatever is happening with calculus, that part matters most right now.

my therapist wants me to try an SSRI and i'm really resistant to the idea. i've had depression on and off for like 8 years but i feel like if i go on medication i'm admitting i can't handle it myself. she's been bringing it up for 3 sessions now

SSRIs are commonly prescribed for recurrent depression and are generally considered effective, especially when therapy alone hasn't resolved symptoms over a long period. Many people use them short-term or long-term with good results. It's worth having a detailed conversation with your therapist and potentially a psychiatrist about what to expect.

i basically rewrote a whole project proposal that my team had been working on for weeks because i could see it wasn't going in the right direction. my manager loved it and we're moving forward with my version. my teammates seem a little cold now but tbh the old version wasn't good. was i wrong to just do it

Improving a proposal when you can see a better direction is sometimes necessary, especially if the project outcome matters. The friction with teammates is a separate issue — acknowledging their work and explaining your reasoning might help repair that.

asking for my dad (68) — he retired last year and literally just sits in his chair all day watching news, my mum says he seems depressed but he won't talk about it. is this just what retirement is like

This is a common pattern in early retirement, especially for men who had strong professional identities. It can tip into clinical depression. Encouraging regular physical activity, social contact, or a structured hobby often helps — if it persists, a GP visit to rule out depression is worth suggesting.

tried negotiating my salary again when they gave me my annual review. asked for 12%, they came back with 3% 'due to budget constraints.' i asked if we could revisit in 6 months and they said sure but honestly that feels like a no. been here 6 years

Get a competing offer from another company — that's the most effective leverage for a real salary negotiation. Research market rates on Glassdoor and Levels.fyi, update your resume, and start interviewing so you have a concrete number to bring back to your employer.

okay so i got into grad school in boston but my boyfriend of 4 years is in seattle and he's not moving. he says he 'supports' me but also keeps bringing up how long distance never works. i already deferred once and the deadline to accept is friday. i don't even know what i'm asking

Long distance is hard but not impossible, especially for a defined period like grad school. Before Friday, it's worth having a direct conversation with him about what 'support' actually means in practice — visit schedule, communication expectations, a timeline. That clarity will help you decide.

been getting calls from collections for months and my sister says i should just ignore them and they'll eventually give up and go away. honestly feels easier than dealing with it so that's probably what i'm gonna do

Your sister's advice isn't quite right. Ignoring collections can lead to lawsuits, wage garnishment, and lasting credit damage — they don't just give up. Responding (even just to verify the debt is legitimate) actually gives you more legal protections under the FDCPA than staying silent does.

Been in the same middle management role for 11 years. Put in for the VP position when it opened up last spring, didn't get it — they hired external. Fine. But now I've started reporting to that person, who is 15 years younger than me and keeps asking me to explain things I built. I went to HR about the adjustment period and they gave me pamphlets about 'change management.' I don't need pamphlets.

Frame your institutional knowledge as an asset in your new reporting relationship by proactively sharing context and documentation rather than waiting to be asked. Building early credibility with your new manager can help reposition you as a key partner, and setting up a regular 1:1 gives you space to discuss your own growth path going forward.

My husband and I are moving across the country next month for his job. We've been in Chicago 22 years, my whole family is here, my friends, my garden. He's very excited. I keep telling people I'm excited too. I'm not sure I am. But I think it's the right thing to do for us, right? Marriages are about compromise.

Compromise is absolutely central to a strong marriage, and supporting each other's career opportunities is part of that. It's also natural to feel some sadness about leaving a place you love — both things can be true at once.

i've been doing doordash on weekends to make extra cash but it's not really adding up. someone in a facebook group said i can make way more doing crypto trading and offered to teach me his 'system' for $400. i'm tempted honestly

Paid trading 'systems' sold in Facebook groups are very rarely legitimate — most profit from selling courses, not from the strategy itself. If you want to explore crypto, there are free resources (Investopedia, YouTube) that cover the basics without the $400 upfront cost.

my manager told me to 'take care of myself' after i missed two deadlines last month. i laughed it off, it's not burnout or anything, i'm just a little tired. do you think green tea has enough caffeine to actually help or should i switch back to coffee

Green tea has about 30–50mg of caffeine per cup compared to coffee's 80–100mg, so if you need a stronger effect, coffee is more reliable. Green tea's caffeine is sometimes described as smoother due to the presence of L-theanine, but it won't match coffee for a significant energy boost.

been living in my van for 8 months doing the nomad thing and i love it but my lease on a storage unit is up and i have to decide whether to get rid of basically all my stuff permanently or rent another unit. keeping the unit feels like admitting i'm going back. am i overthinking this

Whether to keep the storage unit comes down to cost versus the value of having your belongings accessible. If the monthly fee is manageable and you're uncertain about your long-term plans, keeping it gives you flexibility. If you're confident in the lifestyle and the cost adds up, letting it go makes practical sense.

i got laid off in november and i've been living off savings but i'm down to like $6k left. i have a job offer for $58k which is less than i made before ($71k) but i don't know how long i can keep waiting. interviews are slow. should i just take it

With $6k in savings and a slow hiring market, accepting the $58k offer is a reasonable choice. You can continue job searching after you're employed, and having income will reduce financial pressure. The salary gap is real but may be worth the stability.

so I've been putting literally everything on my credit card this past month because my checking account was getting too low and I figured I'd just pay it off when I get paid next week... that's basically fine right? like everyone does this kind of thing

It's fine as long as you actually pay it off in full next week before any interest accrues. The risk is if something comes up and you can't pay the full balance — credit card interest rates (often 20-30% APR) make carrying a balance expensive fast.

been freelancing for 8 months and honestly not making enough, so im thinking of just not filing taxes this year bc i dont have money to pay what i'll owe anyway. its not like they'll notice one person

If you can't pay your tax bill, the IRS offers installment agreements that let you pay over time — you can apply at IRS.gov after filing. Penalties for not paying are generally lower than penalties for not filing, so it's worth submitting the return even if you can't pay the full amount right now.

i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i just read the first chapter of a book that came out last month and it's basically the same concept?? not exactly but close enough that i feel sick. i don't even know why i'm still doing this

my landlord is raising rent $400 and i literally cannot afford to stay but moving costs money i don't have so i'm thinking i'll just cash out my 401k early to cover the deposit and first month. i'm 34 so it's not like i need it tomorrow

Before you do that, know the actual cost: early 401k withdrawal hits you with a 10% penalty **plus** ordinary income tax on the full amount. At 34, you're likely losing 30-40% of whatever you pull out — so a $5,000 withdrawal might net you only $3,000-$3,500.

Cheaper alternatives worth checking first:
- **Personal loan or credit union loan** — even at high interest, cheaper than the 401k penalty
- **401k loan** (if your plan allows) — you repay yourself with interest, no penalty
- **Local rental assistance programs** — many cover deposits and first month; 211.org can connect you to local options
- **Negotiate with your new landlord** — many will split the deposit across 2-3 months

The 401k early withdrawal is one of the more expensive ways to access money, so it's worth exhausting other options first.

**Federal law protects you from being fired for a single garnishment.** The Consumer Credit Protection Act (CCPA) prohibits employers from firing you because of one garnishment — though this protection doesn't apply if you have multiple simultaneous garnishments.

For the IRS specifically, they typically send a "Notice of Levy" to your employer, which is different from a court garnishment but carries similar legal protections in most states. Your employer is legally required to comply with the levy but cannot legally terminate you for it.

A few practical steps:
- **Call the IRS (1-800-829-1040)** immediately to set up an installment agreement or offer in compromise — this can sometimes stop or reduce the levy before it hits your paycheck
- **An Enrolled Agent or tax attorney** can often negotiate directly with the IRS and may be able to halt the levy quickly
- The IRS generally prefers payment arrangements over levies, so there's often room to negotiate

Dad's been forgetting things more and more. Last Tuesday he left the stove on all night. He's 78 and lives alone and refuses to even talk about it. I live four hours away and I just don't know how long I can keep pretending this is fine

This sounds like early-stage cognitive decline, which is common at his age. Contact your local Area Agency on Aging for resources on remote caregiving and how to approach conversations about safety with an resistant parent. A geriatric care assessment might also help establish a baseline.

Both offers have legitimate cases depending on his priorities. The startup offers faster learning and equity upside but real risk; the consulting firm offers stability and credential-building. The right choice depends on his financial obligations, risk tolerance, and what kind of work he wants to be doing day-to-day — those factors matter more than the general startup vs. corporate framing.

ok so i have my CPA exam part 2 in 6 weeks and i failed part 1 twice already. i've been studying every night after work and i genuinely cannot tell if i'm getting better or just going in circles. spent $400 on a becker course and i don't even know if it's helping. my firm knows i'm sitting for it again and if i fail this one i think they're going to let me go. like it's not official but my manager made a comment about 'timeline expectations.' i don't even know what to ask i just feel like something is wrong with how i'm studying but i can't figure out what

You said you can't tell if you're getting better or going in circles — that's actually a diagnosable problem, and it usually comes down to one thing: **passive review instead of active testing**.

Most people who study "every night" are re-reading notes or rewatching lectures, which feels productive but doesn't build the retrieval pathways the exam tests. The fix is to flip your ratio — if you're spending 70% of your time on content and 30% on practice questions, reverse it.

A few concrete things to check:

- **Are you tracking your MCQ scores by topic over time?** Becker lets you do this. If you're not, you have no signal on whether you're improving — you're just studying into the void.
- **Are you doing simulations (TBSs), or mostly MCQs?** Part 2 (FAR or whichever section) has a heavy simulation component and people chronically under-practice those.
- **When you get something wrong, what do you do?** If the answer is "read the explanation and move on," that's the core problem. You need to re-do wrong questions 24-48 hours later until you're getting them right cold.

With 6 weeks, you have enough time, but not enough time to keep doing what isn't working. Which section is Part 2 for you — FAR, REG, BEC, AUD? That'll change what to prioritize.
honest question how do you know when youre just tired vs when somethings actually wrong. like medically

General rule: ordinary fatigue improves with rest and has a clear cause (bad sleep, stress, illness). Persistent exhaustion that doesn't resolve after adequate sleep, lasts more than a few weeks, or comes with other symptoms like weight changes or pain is worth flagging to a doctor.

I'm 44 and I've been feeling exhausted and kind of flat for months. I finally looked it up and I'm pretty sure it's perimenopause. Of the three, black cohosh has the most research support for hot flashes and mood symptoms. Maca root has some evidence for energy and libido, and evening primrose is more commonly used for breast tenderness. They're generally safe to take together, though it may take 6–8 weeks to notice effects.
